    Changing ourselves is never easy. Usually it would take one dramatic or traumatic experience to finally give one a slap at the face that they need to change themselves. Let's take one bad habit - drinking for example. It's easy to drown ourselves in cheap beers and vodka and forget our problems for one night but the next day, when soberness kicks in along with the painful hangover, reality kicks you twice as hard. Your problems didn't disappear. You do it again that night and the night after that and again the next day until your kidney throws in the towel. Your problems still haven't been solved and now you gotta think about that kidney operation. Only then will you start to think rationally and face your original problems instead of running away and stop drinking for once. It's when we hit our lowest points, we are the most susceptible to change.  
 
K-On! is a story about change but it doesn't involve any traumatic experience at all. K-On! is a light, fluffy and heart-warming story of five high school girls and their daily lives in the light music club, more specifically - the story of Hirasawa Yui wanting to finally do something meaningful in her life and stray away from her incompetent, lazy, oblivious and irresponsible self. With help from her childhood friend Nodoka, she finds her way to the light music club and they needed a guitarist. Yui then decides to pick one up even with zero knowledge of playing one. Towards the resolution, Yui is a different Yui from the first episode. She becomes more responsible and reliable. Although it took her quite a while but it proves that with the right guidance, change is possible. 
 
Due to the fact that it was based on a 4 panel manga of the same name, the punchline is always spot on. The jokes - albeit more cuter rather than funny, works well for me. While the plot moves very quickly each episode, it manages to highlight each and every one of the individual characters including the side characters, Nodoka, Ui and Sawaka. The animation and art drastically changed in season 2, making the first season look like a lazy excuse to not deliver the same quality though it's not unforgivable because it may be due to limited budget or whatnot. Giving the audio a solid 10 is a no-brainer. I mean, have you heard their songs and BGM? (Fun fact: the voice actors also held concerts where in some of their songs, they play the instruments themselves). Toyosaki Aki, the voice of Hirasawa Yui was a friggin revelation.  
 
Overall, I thoroughly enjoyed it. The weakest part of the series is actually the story since it was based on a 4 panel manga and there's only 13 episodes.

    K-On! was an anime of it's time and it certainly hasn't aged well. If I had watched when if first came out, chances are I would've been all over, but that isn't the case now.  
 
Now it all seems it's just the same thing all over again, cute girls being cute. Oh, guess what, it's different because they play music! I don't really see it as something memorable or anything that would set standards (like other music SOL anime). 
 
But, if you're into that, watch K-On!  
 
Story: 4/10  
 
I forgive it for not having too clear of a plot as it's a slice of life, but I will say as an anime that I went in thinking I wouldn't have to pay too close attention to it, having others telling me that them growing up is the story, which is, quite frankly, boring. I can't say that's even easy for me to say for it's a reach to make in my eyes.  
 
Art: 6/10 
 
I have nothing else to say other than I thought it was cute until I noticed a variety of other anime with the same exact style. Otherwise, there's some issues with the animation and how they shoot scenes.  But the fact this anime came out in 2009 needs to be taken in to account.  
 
Sounds: 5/10 
 
The music is bland and generic. It sounds as if they're trying too hard to be cute or to fit in with the "anime music". Even the BGM is generic. But... the voice actors are pretty good, even Yui's (despite the fact I honestly despise Yui's voice because of how high pitched and grating it is, her singing voice is even worse).  
 
Character: 5/10  
 
They are all very, very stereotypical and fit into a sub type somehow. All of the characters can be seen as unbearable and obnoxious if someone can't stand moe girls.  
 
The only thing I really appreciated was the subtle character development, my favorite being Mio as it appeared to be the most realistic and something I could relate to. 
 
Enjoyment: 6/10 
 
I enjoyed it while I watched it and nothing more. I wouldn't want to rewatch it because then I would start nitpicking it more than I already have. It's something to turn off your mind to and that wasn't the easiest for me to do. K-On! isn't my cup of tea, but I can certainly see how it can be someone's favorite.   
 
Overall: 5/10  
  
Mediocre. K-On! just isn't supposed to be seen as something deep or meaningful, it's something fun and cute other people can enjoy. If you're expecting something unique and different... Well...

    This is the type of Anime that you watch just because of how cute it is, and let me tell you, it's very cute. 
 
The story is about a high school girl named 'Yui', who at first doesn't know anything about music, or guitars. She joins the Light Music Club in hopes of maybe finding something she can outlet to, and make some friends with; and it works out great! 
 
Art and Sound are amazingly well done! It's not too over the top, but it's just right. And the OP is highly addictive! 
 
Characters at first were a bit bland to me. But, as usual, I've grown to love them and their unique quirks that they offer through the show. The characters are really a highlight here. 
  
Lastly, this anime may be a bit boring at first. But I assure you that it's well worth the watch! The characters are definitely memorable, and the OP is super addicting! I will be watching this one again. 
 
Also, me, being someone who makes music and knows quite a bit about music theory, found this Anime to be very interesting to watch. And I'm not going to lie, but I learned a few things I had no idea about!

    THIS REVIEW CONTAINS SPOILERS 
 
Non-spoiler version: 
Story: 1; it was very predictable and didn't have any interesting themes. They barely did what we were promised that we were going to see. 
Art: 8; This was actually very good. It was cute, had a nice style and the animation was good. 
Music: 7; This was good too. The OP and the songs that the band performed were very good. But the background music and the ED wasn't very good (it didn't really have the same style as the rest of the music) 
Characters: 2: The characters were even more predictable and one-sided. 
Enjoyment: 3; the predictable and one-sided story and characters made it less enjoyable, but it was extremely cute.  
 
Overall: 3 
 
 
 
Spoiler review: 
 
Story: It was very predictable and forgettable. They didn't do anything interesting, they barely played in the group. Did they expect me to believe that Yui learned to play guitar after like 2 times of playing? They just drink tea and eat cookies for the majority of the time. And the 13th episode was very weird. It felt like they wanted to change it into a drama at the end of the first season, and then changed their mind in the last 5 minutes of the episode. 
 
Art: OK, this was actually very good. It was cute, the style was nice and the animation was smooth. 
 
Music: I really liked the OP and the music that the Band performs. But the background music was very forgettable. And then we have the ED which was extremely out-of-place 
 
Characters:  
Let's see what characters we had. 
 
Yui: extremely one-sided and had no character development. She begins as a child in a 15-year-olds body and ends up as a child in a 15-year-olds body. She didn't show any other characteristics other than being happy and childish. 
 
Mio: She was the only one that wasn't as one-sided as the other ones, but she was definitely the most predictable one. She was always scared of something that Ritsu showed and then she would punch Ritsu which was apparently supposed to be funny. It was never funny. But I have to say that she is a shy and introverted character that doesn't go over-the-top, which is good.  
 
Tsumugi: She didn't really have a character. She was happy and was rich. She was basically there to be rich. I don't really have anything else to say 
 
Azusa: She was basically a combination of Tsumugi and Mio.  
 
Ritsu: She was just annoying 
 
Yamanaka: I liked her in the beginning. She was nice. And then they mention her also performing music back in the day and it was like it triggered something in her. After that, she becomes creepy, perverted, annoying and in general not nice. She had a line where she said that she could know the difference between Mio and Azusa by feeling their breast size. Think about that for a second. Their teacher just tried to sexually harass them. THEIR TEACHER TRIED TO GRAB THEIR BREAST! 
 
Enjoyment: 3; The characters and the story made me furious. But it was extremely cute 
 
Overall 3

    This anime is an absolute masterpiece. The characters go through a wide range of emotions and continue to grow, even in the last episodes. The dynamics and the attitudes of both the girls' interactions and the music that they play is truly a testament to the writers' abilities. The art style gives the characters life and perfectly display their emotions, while giving the background a depth that is often neglected. 
This anime combines the slice of life genre so perfectly with a musical setting, that sometimes during the musical segments you forget that this is an anime about high school girls. The music is legitimately good and will be stuck in your head for days if not weeks after watching. 
The dialogue is cute, as is typical of CGDCT anime but has a lot of interplay between characters. The yuri undertones are unsettling at times, as the age difference between some of the characters can be drastic, but it never ventures too far into fan service territory and is often used to enhance the plot of the episode or the series as a whole 
 I deeply enjoyed this anime and it is clearly a benchmark that all CGDCT anime aspires to meet.

    K-On! is by no means an anime for everybody. One can not go into K-On! expecting an intricate story, or deep character development. It is a slice-of-life anime without a season or series long plot, in fact, almost every episode has a different plot (Although, some of them are very similar).  
 
K-On! is very cute. That is probably the first thing everyone will notice about it, and many will be put off by this fact, however after watching a few episodes, I couldn't help but laugh at the silly, childish, and cute humor this series is filled with. 
Some of the humor is recycled (Mostly in this season), and after a while, it will lose its value, but they managed to keep me laughing at least once an episode all the way through.  
 
For most of the series, there is no deep character development. By this, I mean that what you see in the first few episodes, is what you get.  
Yui is hyper, and childish, but cute in her own right. 
Tsumugi is generally quiet, and appears graceful, but often proves to be just as childish as Yui. 
Mio is the most mature of the initial four main characters, but her own shadow would scare her to the point of defecation (Which you'd better get used to, as it is probably the most recycled joke in the first season).  
and finally, Ritsu, who is much like Yui, except much less memorable. She also plays the drums. Ritsu is generally the least liked of the main cast, because there's really nothing unique about her aside from her tomboy-ish style.  
 
 
K-On! is well worth watching, and I would recommend everyone to continue to K-On!!(S2)  even if you didn't like the first season. K-On!! fixes many of the problems that existed in the first season. 
 
In conclusion, K-On! is one of my favorite series of all time (Anime or otherwise), and near the end of the series, it pulled my heartstrings in a way I never thought an animated show could.  
 
If you haven't watched K-On!, do it. Now. Why are you still reading this?

    "Fun things are fun!" 
--Yui Hirasawa 
 
((Reviewer's Note: This is a review that only discusses the first season of K-On! There are mild to moderate spoilers below the fold, you have been warned.)) 
 
K-On! is a show that everyone, whether they have seen it or not, is very quick to form an opinion on. It was perhaps the culmination of the "moe" trend in anime, pioneered specifically by the creative minds at Kyoto Animation, into practically the formation of its own genre in 2009. KyoAni was riding high on the success of Haruhi Suzumiya's first season in the late 2000s, and specifically the most iconic scene in the series, the epic rock concert at the end of episode 12. So why not adapt a four-panel manga series about a bunch of cute girls learning to play in a rock band? And thus, K-On! the anime was born, and the rest is history. 
 
Where K-On really excels as a show is in the very close attention to detail that comes out in every frame. The characters are drawn cutely but with a dose of realism. Their body types are rather normal for a high-school girl. Their uniforms are regulation-length. The fanservice is kept to a minimum, and what is there makes sense within the events of the storyline. 
 
Characterization can make or break slice-of-life shows. Characters you want to see on screen can overcome a lack of any driving plot structure. K-On manages to make its characters engaging, lovable, and always fun to watch. You could put these five girls in just about any situation and the results would be something worth your time. The characters also evolve and change, none more than the presumptive main heroine, Yui Hirasawa.  
 
Yui starts off the show as someone who might be charitably called "attention-deficient" and might uncharitably be called "an idiot". Over time, as she joins the Light Music Club and gets closer to the rest of the girls passing their time in the small, somewhat cramped club room, a change begins to take place over her, and it happens so carefully and with such subtlety that by the time you notice it you'll be done with the first season. 
 
The other girls all complement each other in a variety of different ways, and scenes play out very differently depending on who is there. Tsumugi Kotobuki is a wealthy girl with a heart of absolute gold. Mio Akiyama is a big scaredy-cat and doesn't enjoy being in the limelight no matter how often the girls press her to embrace her role as the face of the band. Ritsu Tainaka is a troublemaker and riffs off the other girls effortlessly, and her comedic portions are perhaps tied with Yui's coming-of-age as the best part of this first season. Very late in the season we are introduced to Azusa Nakano, a kouhai to the other girls who joins the Light Music Club. Unfortunately, she doesn't get much characterization in the five short episodes she's in. She actually comes across as incredibly redundant since her attitude is a little too similar to Mio and her instrument of choice is the same as Yui's.  
 
The flaws with Azusa's introduction didn't detract much from the characterization of the group as a whole. They all get closer. They all learn from each other. They're all great friends, and one of the big themes of K-On is that your friends can make you something better than you are by yourself. A lot of people like to rag on the show for being "not about music" but it was never about four girls playing music. It was always about four girls growing closer with music as the excuse for them to hang out after school. The music is the backdrop, not the main attraction. 
 
That said, the few songs that are in the show are a great treat. Light, poppy, fun little ditties that absolutely will get stuck in your head long after you've finished watching. The OP and ED are both fantastic visually and aurally, with "Don't Say Lazy" probably being one of the most iconic EDs of the past decade. The background music is solid, and the sound direction is on-point, with great use of silence to focus the viewer's attention during the serious parts of the show. 
 
K-On is far from perfect, however, as the 7 atop this review will attest. The actual plot of the show, as much as there is one, is really stock and won't take anyone by surprise. There is the unfortunate fact that two out of the 13 episodes of the show take place at the beach, and the second one feels like a rehash of the first. As mentioned above, Azusa is introduced so late into the season that it's hard to grow attached to her as much as the original four, and her attitude comes across as needlessly tsundere in a show where it just feels out of place. The art is consistent and solid, but doesn't really go out of its way to strive for any real great effects outside of the great attention to detail. It's just not to the standard I've come to expect from KyoAni, even for its age.  
 
Overall, K-On's first season is a fun ride, a solid, strong introduction to some great characters becoming something greater than they were at the start through the power of music, snacks, and love. I enjoyed it, and little did I know that the best was very much yet to come. 
 
But that is a story for another time. Until next time, may the cute things in your life always have cute girls to do them.

    K-On to me is an odd show, an odd show that stands out to me.

Art (9) - I love looking at the environment and the art style this show brings us, I can tell all the characters apart and the backgrounds look clear as day. Same animation can be a bit still and awkward though.

    Funny - Cute - Plotless 
 
If these words are ones that don't leave any negative thoughts in your head, you'll probably enjoy K-On! quite a bit. It's a harmless show that has no real themes, morals, or plot of any kind. It's just a show that is all about having fun. Plain and simple. 
 
Despite what you may think beforehand, the truth of the matter is that there is no plot. Yes, certain episodes have some small roadblock for certain characters, but really, there's mainly nothing going on plot-wise in this anime. I don't necessarily have a problem with that. Lucky Star has no plot, and yet, it is one of my favorite anime of all time. It works due to the humor and characters. When it comes to K-On!, the humor is pretty good for the most part. It definitely had me laughing at certain parts that were silly and stupid, but in a cute way. None of the humor deals with fanservice or adult jokes of any kind. It's very safe. Some people may not like that, but I greatly enjoyed every minute. One thing to keep in mind is that this isn't an anime where we get band songs every episode. There's probably three times where we see the characters play together. Just something to keep in mind. 
 
It's no surprise to anyone that the animation and character designs are beautifully crafted. It's a show that looks as amazing as one would assume from KyoAni.  
 
Music here is definitely above average. I wouldn't cal it groundbreaking or anything. The songs played by the characters in the anime are all rock. They're well composed and everything, but not very memorable. Same with the OP and ED. Good, but slowly drifts away from the mind after watching an episode.  
 
The characters in K-On! are quite enjoyable too. They all have the traits you would assume from this type of anime. None really grow or transform that much throughout the series. Yui provides most of the comedy in the series. She's great. Her humor always hits a good note (no pun intended). One of my favorite jokes in the series deals with her and a guitar. I won't spoil it for you, but you'll know it when it happens. It's comedy gold.  
 
Did I enjoy K-On!? Yeah, but it never went over the hill for me. Sure, the humor works, but it isn't as strong as other slice of life anime. The characters were all enjoyable to watch, especially Yui. There weren't any characters I disliked or found annoying. With that said, they weren't anything to write home about ether. At the end of the day, this is a very good anime that will entertain you while watching it. With that said, it's not life-changing. I wouldn't recommend going out of your way to see it, but if you have nothing better to watch, it's a fun way to waste time and have some great laughs. Don't expect anything deep though.

    This Animie should not enchant me as it does; the story is mostly non existent, the music is too few and far between (although brilliant when it is being played) and most of all it is largely inane and somewhat pointless.  
 
However, despite these flaws, the characters bring out a strange side of me where I'm enthralled by even the most inane of their actions, they have created characters where development is not needed as they are already so freaking cute, I can't but love every second of the show.   
 
Watching the idealistic lives of several girls who don't have to deal with any problems that would usually turn me off slice of life shows (Usually boys .... my god that bores me senseless), I feel about as relaxed as I can be, their inane chatter is soothing, their problems solvable yet the great voice acting and character design (English version dub) makes me empathize with them to a point where i start to care about their inane problems.  
 
To summarize, i would recommend anyone to watch this show, I doubt everyone will like it,  but if you are not turned off of it by episode 4 then I would bet you will have a new top Animie.  
 
Inane but irresistible

Props because the songs in the show are pretty good as well as the art work.(btw if you seen Black rock shooter the art work for that show is pretty much the same)  but what was lacking was a real plot. Girl join club, club makes band, band practice, band preforms at school festival  and this goes for the whole show. It was good but not that great of a anime.

    Okay, K-On! is hands down one of the best slice-of-life anime I've ever seen. Firstly I'm going to give a brief summary on what this anime entails. Secondly, I'm going to say why you should watch this anime! 
 
This anime revolves around Yui Hirasawa and her high school friends. She has just started high school and has no idea which club she wants to join. She finally meets Ritsu and Mio, who coerse her into joining the group even though she has no idea how to play any instruments. We then follow her journey on becoming an aspiring guitar player and laughing along with her and her friends silly 
 
This anime surprised me as how it could suck in the viewers to instinctively love all of the characters. There aren't many slice-of-life anime that I have been so attracted to. I really liked how viewers can learn a little something about music while laughing at Yui and her friends goofing around. It is not very different from other slice-of-life anime, except for the music core and atmosphere. I cannot stress how much the atmosphere of this anime just got me so excited to watch episode after episode.  
 
If you're into music oriented anime, and just loving a genuine fun show, where you can connect with the characters, this is the anime for you!

    2 years after my leave from my anime community, K-ON has somehow wiggled it's way into my daily life yet again. Now,  I at least have some wisdom to write a formal review (unlike 2 years ago *shudder*). 
 
K-ON! is a moeblob anime targeted for the shojo audience, but does have some seinen elements like its manga counterpart. Being in the shojo demographic myself, I found it very appealing, enojoyable, and somewhat relatable. The art is good, being managed by KyoAni, with a proper amount of chibi scenes and vivid animeaation during EDs/OPs (great detail in individual playing). However, during the start of the anime, there is some asymmetry and choppy frames. The sound is great as well, songs made to fit with the feel of the anime. The lyrics can get a little too fluffy/meaningless. Songs from the soundtrack really make up for that, though. The character development is pretty good in most areas, except for Yui and Mugi. There is great chemistry between Mio and Ritsu, and some other underlying yuri tones help bring other good chemistry out from the other characters (totally not biased because of my love of yuri). But Yui and Mugi I feel don't go through as much change as the others. Yui is always ditsy with her occasional sense of "this is what I was meant to do" and "this group is my destiny" in key areas, but I feel her personality is too moe and cliche. Mugi has barely any background and sometimes I feel like she's there just to provide the club deus-ex-machina-esque moments. Besides that, she only has the small lines which barely make an impact on the overall story. 
But, the enjoyment (for my age at least) is a 10. I really felt like the everyday adventures of the club were easy to watch for me, relaxing. However, don't expect Evangelion, because you aren't going to get many poetic moments or major gravity in the show, as that's not what it's about. 
The story is, as I said before, great for shojo and/or slow-going slice of life lovers, but can appeal to grown men if they like moeblob. 
Overall, it's an 9 from me, regardless of how much I love this show (I really love this show).

    Quite frankly i can sum this anime up in two words. Tea Party.  
 
The concept of tea is supposed to generate a feeling of relaxation or something that's laid back. This anime accomplishes this in a refreshing way but does not really astound appealing more to the niche moe genre than trying to actually do anything with the material they have.  
 
The characters are nice and cute and the art is nice and cute..... hell i think this entire show is based around nice and cute. It's an enjoyable watch but don't expect too much story. This anime is ultimately about the characters and whether or not you like this anime hinges on whether or not you like the characters. Most of the archetypes are there so this shouldn't be anything too painful to watch, just expect less music than they would lead you to believe.

    The first time I watched this series, I dropped in the middle of the first episode, because I couldn't stand Yui's character. But months later when I gave it another shot, I loved K-On, it is now even one of my favorite anime. I no longer found Yui irritating, but rather so cute. I would never know why. 
 
Story (9) 
The story is very simple. It's hard to say that there is a main plot, actually. Well it's to be expected, I guess, since it's a Slice of Life genre. But each episode has a quite good story, so it didn't bother me too much. I know that there are people who prefer an anime with a solid main plot, but it isn't bad to have this kind time to time.  
 
Art (10) 
One of the biggest asset of this series. The art is amazingly done, the characters are drawn ever so cutely and the animation's terrific too. 
 
Sound (10) 
Another biggest asset. Openings, endings, BGMs, insert songs, everything was fantastic. The main character's voice (who sings pretty much all the songs) could be annoying to some; I even so people complaining why Mio isn't the one singing. But you're forgetting something here. This series features moe stuff. In my opinion, Yui's voice is THE moe voice. I don't know how to explain this, you just have to hear her voice, I guess. 
And the seiyuus have done a terrific job, too. 
 
Character (9) 
I could say that the characters are quite the sterotypes- the air-headed one, the popular one, the boyish one, the rich one, and the youngest one. And the characters are very shallow, by which I mean that we don't really know anything of their past, etc. Alas, it doesn't stop us to squeal over this girls. You don't feel any of this while watching the series. 
 
Enjoyment (10)  
 
Overall (10) 
Watch it, watch it, watch it.

    Just Finished K-On!! (Both seasons and will most likely have this same review for the 2nd Season Review page, just because they're the same Anime.) 
 
My expectations for it may have been high, But I will say, It didn't disappoint. 
It was great all around, It had its Happy Moments, Its (somewhat) serious moments, but most of it was all fun.  The music was Great(and incredibly Addicting).  Especially their one song that you hear most of the time; 
"Fuwa Fuwa Time" 
 
As for Story, the Story was kind of Hard to Follow, But in a Good Way.  Thats whats to fun about this one.  If your Looking for Deep story in a Musical Anime, look for Tari Tari or something like that.  This one is Just for Fun, and Enjoyment. 
 
The Art was "old-fashioned" in a good way as well.  Compared to all the new anime, where its like, I cant quite explain it, but the Art in this one was Great for the type of anime it was.  Each type of thing symbolised what each character had.  With Kotobuki's Enormus Eyebrows symbolizing that she was the daughter of the guy that owned that music store, or that the Hair Style Between Ui and Yui symbolised who was more childish and who was the more serious one. 
 
The sound in terms of the Music was FANTASTIC!  The songs were really catchy, and the names were really cheery and happy.  it made me smile every time their songs were playing, and it made me want to hear the whole thing(because they always seemed to cut off) 
 
The Characters were...  Odd, but thats whats refreshing about this anime.  Its different from the rest, and I really liked that about this one.  With Yui's Child-like Attitude, or Meo's Seriousness, It made it fun whenever they were all talking about something, and then something would happen, and someone would do something funny then they'd all laugh. 
 
Enjoyment?  Heh.  HELLZ YEAH I ENJOYED IT!!!  It was Catchy, Fun, and Incredibly Addicting to sing Fuwa Fuwa Time everytime they would sing it.  When they would sing their songs during the Cultural Festivals, I would Clap with the song.  It was an anime that had me sucked in to the very end.(Season 2 as well) 
 
Overall, It was Great, and Different and I really Liked it. 
 
The Name of the band was "After-school Tea Time(Hōkago tītaimu)" or HTT for Short. 
The way they had the characters set up was, kinda weird, but I liked it. It was different from you usual Song Type anime.  It was always bringing something fun to each episode and I was looking forward to the next episode after I would finish the last. 
 
Highly Recommend it to Anyone looking to have a great time.

    This is my first review, please don't expect too much. Also, it may say that I haven't seen all the episodes. That is because I rewatch this show from time to time. 
 
Keion, better known as “K-On!” is a Slice-of-Life anime based on five adorable girls and their efforts in “The Light Music Club.” K-On was a show I watched based off of the recommendations section I saw for the anime “Kokoro Connect.” And boy was I glad that I did. Before I begin I would like to warn you that K-On is a show about “cute girls doing cute things.” If you aren’t really into that kind of stuff I would go look for a different show. Now, let’s get started. 
 
The Characters: 
The first episode of “K-on!” introduces us to the first four main characters. The great thing about this show is that they all have their own original personality and none of the girls really give off the same type of vibe. You have Ritsu, the drummer. Ritsu is the wild one of the group. She attempts to get the group to go along with her silly ideas and usually goes all out against the ideas she doesn’t like. Ritsu is very lively and is able to keep the show a lot more interesting. Then there is her childhood friend, Mio, the Bass player and sometimes singer. Mio is the shy one, and having Ritsu as her best friend, it creates some interesting situations. Sometimes she gets really embarrassed and it she becomes very lovable to watch. Ritsu helps push her through her fears, giving us a fun dynamic duo to watch. Next is Yui, the lead guitarist and singer.  She is really the key character of this show, because it’s mostly about her life. Yui is a really lazy airhead who is on the verge of being a “NEET.” She enters the light music club thinking that it was something completely different. Watching her grow as a guitarist is enjoyable to watch, and proves for great character development. Finally is Mugi the pianist, whom personally is my favorite character is the silly rich girl. She doesn’t really know about more common things such as fast food joints and arcades, and it puts up for some great comedy. It was funny to watch her learn about all the things that we “middle-class” have to put up with and what we do for fun. Finally, is the rhythm guitarist Azusa.   She isn’t introduced to later after the first four go through their freshmen year. She is one year younger than the other four, and is the same age as Yui’s sister Ui. She is the girl who tries to get the club to actually practice music and not laze around the whole time. Her go-getter attitude is what makes her cute and fun to watch. All of the side characters are quite the cool bunch as well. They all provide more humor and play well with the main characters. 
 
The Story: 
	As I said earlier this show is about “The Light Music Club” or Keion Club (K-On! The title is a play-off of this.) At first there are zero members in the club and it is about to be disbanded. But Ritsu while forcing Mio, begin to bring the club back to life attempting to get the required four members.  Eventually Mugi, looking for the choir club, and Yui, who is looking for something easy end up joining the duo meeting this requirement. The Light Music Club’s main focus IS SUPPOSE to be playing “Light-hearted” music as their advisor Sawako calls it; but they actually don’t really do much but drink tea and eat snacks. Well you may now be wondering, “How can a show like this be any good at all?” Well the main reason behind it is because it is just really funny and the jokes that end up being made within the show are so great and memorable. There are also the bonds between the characters. The main ones of Mio and Ritsu and Yui and Azusa are just so cute to watch. The way they end up working together to get their problems solved, such as finding a way to get Yui her first guitar, to the camaraderie between the friends, puts such a fine feeling within you, causing you to beg for more. With the hardships of getting through school and practicing music, this show gives me some of the most fun I have ever had. 
 
Music: 
	Do you like J-Pop? If you do you will surely love the music presented by The Light Music Club’s band known as “After School Tea Time.” They actually members of the Japanese cast sing all of the songs that the band in the show sings. The music is crisp and soothing and is a joy to listen to. I actually have put many of the songs on CDs to listen to in my car. There is also the background music. It’s very cheerful and playful but none of it is really too ground breaking like “Ring Ring Ring!” from the show “Little Busters!” While the background music is really nothing too memorable, the OPs, EDs, and insert songs keep you coming back for more. 
 
Art: 
	The art to this show is absolutely phenomenal. Of course, this is nothing unexpected of Kyoto Animation, who have produced masterpieces such as Kanon, and Lucky Star. The art is all fluid and clear, very pleasing to the eyes. I personally enjoyed how they do a few of the performance scenes, as they use well worked camera angles to show the audience, and the emotion of the band themselves. As usual I would say that Kyoto Animation hit another homerun art wise. 
 
Final Remarks: 
I waited until now to reveal that “K-On!”  is my favorite show, or at least one of them. The only show that stands with it would be the original Pokemon (Kanto and Johto series.) I have purchased all episodes as well as the movie and even have most of the songs from the show on my Nook (Yes I use a Nook for music). K-On has been my favorite show even after watching about 80 more series. With that K-On does receive a 10/10. Thanks for reading and I hope you check it out.

    The strange and (in my opinion) great thing about K-on is that it is pointlessly entertaining. 
 
The story is pretty cliche yes, and it never strays from the guidelines of slice-of-life, but the way I see it, K-on specialises (and does a damn good job) in delivering straightforward, lighthearted fun. I really loved that there was no drama or romance (as it can make you dislike characters) and that the main character is never treated as the underdog; it was without the frustration (if done badly)of watching characters overcome social rejection.The characters are easy-going and lovable, and they actually drive the fun and aren't boring like most female slice-of-life characters. You can't help feeling carefree when both story and characters treat life like one long tea party! 
 
I personally love this anime so I'm nitpicking, but there's no real sense of accomplishment by the end of this anime. Whether it's because of the lack of training montages or because the songs are a bit rubbish, you don't really care too much about the fact that they're in a band. However, you can't be a band without being friends, and that friendship comes across strongly in K-on. 
 
It always boggles my mind when I scroll through the completely K-on free top 100 on the anime list; people are so critical! Sometimes you don't want to engage in anime. All the long exposition and the static dialogue scenes and the slow development can feel like a chore. Sometimes you need to leave it to K-on, and turn off!

    K-on! presents itself to the average viewer as another ordinary high-school, slice-of-life form of anime with nothing to appealing about it aside from the interesting enough exclamation mark in the title. Upon further investigation I came upon an anime that was indeed that but with a musical twist to it which is applied albeit in a minimal fashion. 
 
The story itself is weak, with no easily identifiable goals or ending point and rather simply follows the 4 main characters around on their yearly adventures as your typical high-school girl clique. If anything the only identifiable form of anchoring that holds the plot together is the presence of music. The story does however, serve its purpose as a light anime to watch whenever you so choose as its lack of plot makes it fairly easy to pick up at any point. 
 
The character development is fair, nothing to spectacular but nothing left to be desired. The strength in what the series has done however, is build an attachment to the characters by their antics. However, once again, it's your typical group of 4 with nothing too spectacular in terms of breaking the mold. 
 
The main form of enjoyment to be found in this anime was rather the antics  
presented and the constant sources of your atypical slap stick humor.  
 
Overall, I found it to be an enjoyable experience to watch but difficult to watch for long periods of time due to the semi-monotonous tone it gave off after watching 15 or so episodes in a row.

    More or less directly copied from my review on Anime Planet. 
 
----------------------------- 
 
This is my first review, so bear with me. 
 
After finishing Kokoro Connect and its OVA "sequel" Michi Random, I was left with something of a void. Not to the extent of Steins;Gate or Clannad: After Story, but there was a hole in my anime schedule that I thought would be difficult to fill. 
Some people say that if you're stuck on what to watch after finishing a show, then start a show similar to the one that left the void. With this in mind, I decided to watch K-On!. Why? Because the character designs in Kokoro made me think of this show; most likely because the same character designer worked on both shows. 
 
 
Story 
 
As much as the story centres around music, it is still very much a slice of life anime, and as such, there are many times where the characters, rather than practicing, just sit around and do something that isn't club activities - drinking tea, for example. 
 
 
Animation 
 
There's not really much for me to say about animation. As one would expect from Kyoto Animation, the art and animation of this anime is generally well done, particularly the attention to detail regarding the club's equipment. At times, however, the colours in the background would seem a bit dull, though this was counteracted by the characters. 
 
 
Sound 
 
This is where K-On! truly shines. The BGMs, although not too memorable, generally fit with the current on-screen situation. The OP would probably fit onto my top 50 anime opening list, if I were to ever make such a list, and the ED gave off a music-video feeling, with a catchy tune to go with it. 
The episodes that focused on the Light Music Club actually doing music were the highlights of the show for me. The insert songs were great if a bit odd, but unfortunately, only two or three episodes actually had real performances done by the club; the rest were spent on the girls going about their daily lives, as you'd expect from a slice of life show. 
 
 
Characters 
 
There was not a single character that I really disliked throughout the show. Their interactions are the second highlight of the show, with the voice actors really bringing the show's comedy to life. Aki Toyosaki and Yoko Hikasa in particular fit their assigned characters - Yui and Mio, respectively - better than I expected. 
With one or two exceptions, each named character served a purpose towards the story; for example, Yui's best friend Nodoka Manabe, is a member of the school council and generally appeared to move the actual plot along in the form of pushing the club for various application forms. 
 
 
Final thoughts 
 
Overall, K-On! turned out to be better than I expected. I had heard good things about it, so that set some expectations, and they were met, but not really exceeded. 
So in the end, I'd recommend this show if you're looking to take it easy after a shounen action, or just want to kick back in general. 
 
I hope you enjoyed my first review. If there's anything you disagree with, post a comment. Thanks for taking the time to read it! :) 
 
 
Story - 6.8 
Animation - 8.1 
Sound - 8.4 
Characters - 7.3 
Enjoyment - 7.0 
FINAL SCORE - 7.52/10

K-ON Season 1 Review. 
8/10 (Please read the rest) 
Now i am not the biggest slice of life fan but even i can find some enjoyment in the genre. At the tip top of this genre is a little show called K-ON. K-ON is one of the only shows i have seen to work so well with the formula of cute girls doing cute things. To critically review this show wouldn't do it justice as its not supposed to be looked at as a critical masterpiece in the likes of Evangelion or Serial Experiments Lain. This show is just a ball of fun topped with good art and music. 
 
To debunk the common saying that this show is about music, its more about the character interactions with one another and the comedy that follows. Music is just a backdrop to make events happen in the show.  
 
K-ON is cute and moe but that doesn't stop it from being fun. This show isn't as cringy as other shows that try to be like K-ON. It has a nice blend of comedy that doesn't seem that forced. K-ON does have some generic tropes in the characters that make them cringy and predictable but its sometimes overshadowed by lovable characters. As cringy as it can be, it still manages to be fun. 
 
K-ON isn't a perfect show as the voice acting in the dub and sub is weird at times. In addition, the show has a soundtrack that sounds good but is out of place sometimes. The comedy can be subjective from person to person. The comedy can be a bit repetitive and dare i say it, annoying a few times. 
 
To sum it up, K-ON is good and deserved to be watched. Sure, it may have some negatives aspects mainly being repetitive and predictable but i don't feel as if thats a issue that you should take into major consideration. K-ON has the good mix of a nice soundtrack, nice visuals, and great characters. 
 
8/10﻿

Art: 9/10

    It's clear that K-On had a substantial impact on the slice of life genre. It's been 7 years since it came out, and since then both SoL and anime have evolved. Some 2016 tropes don't seem present before K-On, and as a result it's hard to judge it without giving in to "Seinfeld Is Unfunny," that successfully innovative ideas become commonplace and then the source seems unoriginal for attempting them.  
 
With this in mind, a few other things are worth noting. While some SoL's have very intriguing story arcs, the simplicity of the resolutions and even the driving conflicts makes the plot okay, but really not the defining feature. Some challenges are thrown in repeatedly that are resolved without any new character dynamics or revelation. They seem to be there just to pass the time. While it's expected for SoL's not to be plot-driven, it's also expected that the story has some impact on the characters or the viewer's understanding of them. This often isn't the case.  
 
In contrast, the characters themselves are all very well developed. Some traits are introduced and then forgotten, but the characters do have arcs and the dynamic between them is heavily developed (Again, largely outside the plot). They're all believable and empathetic. There is a noteworthy near-exception, Ritsu, a protagonist who feels pretty underdeveloped for much of the anime and it seems like she plays a role only when one of her couple defining traits becomes relevant, and consequently appears a bit flat.  
 
The music is okay or good, but doesn't really seem to stand out in any noteworthy way. Also, the art fluctuates often between great and generic. They act to help convey everything else, and that's fine. There's no shortage of fanservice, but it's not overwhelming. Overall, it's a rather enjoyable show but by the end it feels like they draw on some of the same things too often.  
 
If you're looking for consistently amazing art/music, a strong story, something very unique, or meaningful challenges/conflicts this probably won't appeal to you much. If you want a cute show with likable characters and you don't mind some things seeming generic from reuse since, which was my context for the overall rating, this is worth seeing.

    I watched this on a whim several years ago, due to it becoming popular among my previous group of friends, and the appealing art style.  
Normally, I HATE anime that is moe fanservice-based and has no pretty males, but K-on may be one of the few exceptions to this. 
 
The reason? 
 
Well, the reason I hate such anime in the first place is because I am a feminist, so you can imagine that I hate seeing girls sexualized and used as nothing but pure fap-material(which many men do even for this seeminigly-innocent series). 
 
The reason I was able to tolerate and even enjoy this anime(enough that I would spend $200 on a Tsumugi doll), was because I felt they made the girls somewhat realistic and NOT degraded for moe anime standards. Surprisingly, they weren't sexualized, and they were adorable without being over-the-top annoying like most cutesy anime girls are. 
 
STORY: 
The story was like any typical daily-life anime I had seen before, except, I felt that it was very well-done for daily life anime standards. Something about how they paced it, or perhaps because of how they built up your excitement, it felt pretty good, despite how typical it is for a musical slice of life, when you stop to think about it.  
Actually, this anime is what encouraged me to go and finally get piano lessons! 
Really, the only thing I didn't like of the story was when Mio fell on the stage and accidentally revealed her underwear, as up-skirts are one of my least favorite things about ecchi, but it relieved me that they did not actually show it. 
Also, there is no real conflict at all besides deadlines, grades, and getting Yui to learn the guitar(which she learned quickly). I personally think it would have added to the story if the girls at least had some sort of relationship conflict with each other, and maybe resolved it later on? Maybe if they had a rival at least? 
 
ART: 
It's either the art/animation or the music that makes this anime exceed my expectations. I don't quite know how to explain it in one word, other than "juicy"," squishy", or cute. I really quite love how they drew the characters' eyes and faces overall, and the movement in animation is really fluid, even little things like how their facial expressions change. They don't skim on their facial movements even when they're seen in chibi expressions. The art style for K-on is actually pretty unique, at least until some new anime series' with the same art-style came out afterwards. It will always be the "K-on style" to me, though. 
 
SOUND: 
Probably the best thing, along with the art/animation(possibly #1, though), is the music in this anime. Even to this day, years after the anime was at peak popularity, I still have some of their songs on my playlist. The music in this anime makes it a legit music anime that far exceeded my expectations that I had due to some of my friends saying "only creepy otakus like K-on". 
Although, I am not too fond of the super cutesy soft-sounding songs, I absolutely love the rock-type songs like "Don't say Lazy" and "No thank you!!", as they are so catchy, energetic, and uplifting without being annoyingly cute(the lyrics definitely are cute/happy). 
I should also add that Mio's strong voice in those two songs is quite empowering to hear in comparison to the soft pop songs. 
 
CHARACTER: 
As a person who generally hates cutesy anime girls... I felt that the characters were really charming. I would say that Yui and Mio were my favorite characters personality-wise, and Tsumugi my favorite design-wise(and because she plays the synth/piano). 
I can't say I was too fond of Azusa, but she is definitely cute design-wise. I love her eyes. Other than her design, though, I felt like she was too boring of a character besides the whole cat ears thing. 
One thing I particularly like about the character designs, is that they are not anorexic. They have realistic weights and heights typical of Japanese females in high school, and they get self-conscious about fat just like real girls(but not as annoyingly persistent). 
 
ENJOYMENT: 
This anime was pretty enjoyable for me. Normally, a non-comedy slice of life anime would have long periods of boringness, but this wasn't. It kept you excited through each episode, and something would always happen. 
Watching this kind of felt like I was becoming friends with them myself. You kind of feel like you're a part of their world, and growing with them as new friends. 
While watching this anime, this kept popping into my head: "Are you sure this is made for guys? It's too innocent and girly and friendship-y... It feels more like a cute shoujo anime, only without boys/romance!". 
 
Overall, it's a good anime that is definitely above average compared with other slice-of-life, and I would recommend it to anyone who has free time and wants to watch a light-hearted anime.

    I was having a quick look through the shows I'd reviewed, and really only this, Kids on the Slop and Angel Beats I haven't reviewed, so, this being a favourite (I keep using that word, will have to compile a list!), I thought I'd get on with a review! Let's journey together folks:- 
Story:- The story, surprisingly enough, centers around a highschool student, called Yui. She's cute. I love her. I love all the girls in this anime. And I will get on to the later. Anyway, she can't decide what club she wants to join at school (is club joining compulsory in Japan, or just a "safe" anime plot?), but finally decides to join the Light Music Club, along with Ritsu, Tsumugi, Mio and, later on, Azusa, or cat-girl as she will be reffered to from now on. So, as a band, do these girls work hard every day, and produce some amazing songs? Do they b*lls. You want to know what they do? Sit around, eating cake and drinking tea. No darn joke. Anyway, the first few episodes revolves around Yui trying to raise funds to buy a guitar (WHY?! Why join a music club without an instrument?). She sets her eyes on Gibson Les Paul (who, for you who aren't into guitars, is a beautiful yet dead expensive instrument), but decides she wants it. She doesn't raise the money, but that's OK, because Tsumugi's parents OWN THE DARN SHOP ANYWAY! It deserves a 6/10. 
Art:- The art is very lovely, being your average CGI usage. Nothing splendid, and CGI shouldn't really get points anymore, but it just is so nice. I like it. It's crisp, it's clean, it's just ooooo. Oh, and there's a beach scene. 5 girls, at a private beach hut (because Tsumugi has too much money, well, her parents anyway). 8/10. 
Sound:- Now, I've mentioned this is a "musical" anime. I've also mentioned the lack of songs. However, there are around (no, really) two or three tunes. They're good. They're kinda pop/rock songs. I liked them (or at least, what I remember of them). 7/10. 
Character:- THIS is why I like the anime so much. The girls are adorable! And they're funny, cute, energetic, KAWAII bundles of fun! Sorry, I apoligize for basically saying the same word three times, but just look at Yui's face. *looks up at poster on wall* - just, oooooo, wanna just pinch her little cheeks! I'M A MAN. GRRRR, MOTORBIKES AND SH*T. GGRRR. They are litreally why I rate the anime so high. Really, it's blackmail. If it weren't for the girls, there wouldn't be a second season, nor a movie. But that said, when so much goes into making these characters, you can't help but rate it high anyway. 8/10 from me!

    I will start by saying that friendship animes are my favourites.  
I was not going to watch K-On! with the consciousness that i was going to watch a friendship anime series, so, knowing that it was super cute and moe moe (and so on), i was kind of not super-excited in front of it. My initial thought was something like "Hmm... Another moe anime, yay...".  
I was wrong. Definitly wrong.  
Let me get into it. 
 
Story: 8 
I gave K-On!'s story a mark of 8, because it's kind of the same of every slice of life. 
The show itself develops itself around a group of five girls in highschool, spending time together in a club, the Light Music Club (K-On, itself). 
The majour misconception of this anime, is that it doesn't have a story at all. That it totally not true. 
The growth of the main characters in the environment in which they live and do what they do is the true essence of the K-On!'s story. 
 
Art: 9 
I definitly loved drawings and animation in K-On!, although some scenes could have been better designed, but i suppose that was done on purpose from the producer. 
 
Sound: 10 
I love K-On!'s sound compartment. I love the songs, i love character's voices, i love general ambient sounds. All of them feel so damn real and... Close to reality. Watching the first series ending is more or less just like watching a music video on MTV or something like that. 
Character voices are amazing, they really reflect the true essence of the characters. And this is expecially applied in the songs.  
 
Character: 10 
I will never stop saying that K-On! doesn't want to be a music anime, just like some other animes. K-On! wants to be a friendship anime. K-On!, on the first episode of the first season, wants you to start growing with the characters of the story by enjoying their adventures, their laughings and their music. K-On! wants you to get close to its characters, expecially to the main five girls (Yui, Mio, Ritsu, Azusa and Tsumugi), and know them, grow with them and explore their growing friendship. 
K-On! doesn't want to be a music anime, or a moe anime. It wants to be a friendship anime between five well designed characters, who experience a visible growth during the series. 
 
Enjoyment: 10 
I personally watched the whole series + movie three times, and every time that i watched it i only enjoyed it more. 
The more you know the characters in this anime, the more you want to watch the series, seeing their differences from the beginning to the end of the series itself. 
 
Overall: 10 
K-On! became my favourite anime of all time. I cannot use a shortcut to say why and how it became my favourite anime, because the reason itself stands in the emotions and relationship that the watcher builds and experiences through the series. 
That being said, i cannot do anything but recommend this series to everyone who loves watching animes that are not trivial and simple. K-On! is not like that. 
K-On! surprises you, makes you feel emotions, experience and feel friendship between the main characters just like if they were real. 
--- Kind of spoiler down below --- 
I watched the series in the graduation from highschool period. As you can imagine, in that period, where you're fully concentrated with the exams, you surely cannot realize that many highschool friendships will became memories, simply because life works like that. I went then to university, so our lives got kind of separated. 
K-On! actually ends like that. Four of the main characters are going to graduate, leaving Azusa, the fifth member, alone in the Light Music Club. 
Watching K-On! during my graduation was really painful, and tears were really going down fast. 
Even now, when i listen to the K-On! music in the car, i remember every feeling and emotions that this anime gave to me. 
So yeah, sorry for this review full of grammar errors (i'm not english :P) and repetitions. 
Just wanted to share my personal enjoyment of this, in my opinion underrated and misunderstood, series. 
K-On! <3

    Enjoyment: 10/10 (Really this is the only score that matters) 
 
	Friends are a virtue. You can pursue your dreams all you want but it’s never truly fulfilled without a little help from some friends. They’re there to help you and have fun with you. Maybe you’ll argue time to time, but in the end, you're just a happy family. That’s the heartwarming message K-On!. And while it’s a very happy and cute one, just like the anime, it’s hard to say that this show is something to write home about. 
 
        Before touching on why this isn't the most explosive of animes, I'd like to touch on how this is an anime everyone should watch at some point in their anime-watching life, and not just this season particularly, I mean the whole shindig. Start from season one to the movie and surely this series will bring no regrets; I wasn’t lying about this anime be a very heartfelt one. Not only that but what this anime pulls off animation wise is just unbelievable. Just take a moment to look at the instruments. The insane detail that goes into those drawings are insane. Do a side by side comparison and you’d be surprised at how precise the details are on those instruments. Couple that with the smooth animation and it will leave you breathless just thinking about how much time and effort must of went into just animating this show. Even if the show wasn’t entirely hand drawn and had use of CGI, it’s really impressive how they got the instruments to fit in so well with the cute, anime art style. On the music side of the spectrum, this is personally one of the only animes that I love the music so much that I'd deliberately watch the OP on every episode. It goes without say, this is indeed a music anime. And usually with these “moe” animes it’s all just annoying and cringe-like songs, but the adorable, pop-like Toyosaki Aki paired with Hikasa Yoko’s smooth voice, all with the support of the rocking sound of drums, guitar, and piano/synth, actually comes off as more of a legitimate, pop-rock band than just overblown, “KAWAII” music like Love Live. All this along with lovable characters and endearing moments of fun and troubles (like practically going through an identity crisis), this show is just absolutely rocking and should be given a chance as a stand alone enjoyable experience. But objectively, K-On! as it’s own individual first season is NOT a masterpiece. Heck, not even memorable at times. 
 
        While there are many nit-picky things that affect the show that could be talked at extensively, they are mainly just small things that can be overlooked. Specifically, the main problem this anime suffers from is the lack of impact. This is a very common situation for slice of life animes since they usually don’t have an overarching goal/plot that the characters have to overcome to keep an audience hooked. Instead, it needs to focus on the more comedic side to attract it's audience. And while all the jokes weren't bad, the jokes were mostly a hit-or-miss due to it's heavy focus on picking at their cuteness rather than actual comedy; at that point, we are just making fun of them like a bunch of bullies. You can see this happen in other countless 'moe' animes like Love Live! and Denki-gai. Just because a girl is embarrassed about wearing revealing clothing doesn't mean it's funny; that's called being a girl with a conscience. Comedy is about being clever with word play or hitting hard with the unexpected, and if you don't have that pure comedy for a COMEDY show, them what is this show then? A good example of this is the school festival episode or the formation of the Light Music Club episode. These episodes played off the characters misunderstandings, unexpected traits, and clever interpretations of situations. The great use of the character traits to mess with others is where the comedy is centered at, not the girls be them. Doing that would just reaffirm their behaviors and give them a sense of realism, as if they are real people, but nothing else like the Christmas episode (except Sawa-chan) and the Training Camp episode which is mostly the girls just being lazy or just being cute. There is no need to constantly shove them being cute this in our face, we understand that already and it gets repetitive. Admittedly, there are some funny jokes in those episodes, but not enough to hold attention. If the comedy was more witty, it could have more solid and memorable than what it is now if it weren't for the honest moments of living out the pure student life of high school and sisterly/friendly love. 
 
        Therefore, can you say that this was a bad anime? No, just a tiny bit above average (like a .1 over whatever average is for you). It's a very touching slice of life with great ascetics that drags half of most episodes due to uncreative jokes, but sure can be finished with satisfied hearts, and that's all that really matters with this anime. Find what you can connect most with this anime then just go with it. It for the enjoyment of connecting with a cast of characters that know how it feels to live life to the fullest with the limits you have; it's possible as long as you got friends, lame jokes and all that jazz.

    K-On! is one of those shows that gets tossed around a lot as a great example of a slice of life comedy, being one of the more popular examples of one.  I wanted to branch out and try some more modern anime so I took a chance on this as it is mentioned as a good starting point.   
 
Full Disclosure: I recently got back into watching anime after a very long hiatus.  Cowboy Bebop was the last more or less contemporary show that I watched, so that probably colors my opinion somewhat. 
 
I was hoping to see more about the struggles of putting together a musical performance and how a light music club would operate, but was a bit disappointed that each episode seemed to be more about tea and dessert time and screwing around than actual Light Music.  This could be interesting if it was a couple episodes before the story got a bit more serious/urgent, but it was the story in just about every episode.   
 
To be fair, the story does have somewhat of a progression of time in it, with various activities happening more or less due to the needs of a light music club.  Instruments are acquired, the girls work on the theory of practicing or song writing for a few minutes, and then they are back to doing pretty much what they were doing earlier, which is having a tea party and reacting to their situation in a clichéd way based on their character tropes. 
 
With regards to the technical, the art is ok.  Nothing spectacular.  Animation feels a bit wonky at times.  The sounds are done pretty well, the music that is performed does actually sound like J-pop, and the voice acting doesn’t give me any right to complain.  The opening and closing credits are catchy, and the other songs that are performed work as well.  This is the high-water mark of the show in my opinion.  K-On!’s major stumbles are story and character development. 
 
The characters in K-On! are not very deep or complex, and they pretty much have their one or two shticks that become a punchline repeatedly throughout the series.  I watched the entire first season and past the first two or three episodes, I had figured out what the characters were going to do in most of the situations they were presented with.   
 
The lazy characters were going to be lazy, the timid, serious one was going to freak out about something when she tried to get things back to serious, the refined one was going to make tea to calm everyone down, and the adult in the room was going to try to get the club into cosplay.  That’s basically each episode in total, with perhaps a school festival, beach, or holiday setting to break things up once every couple episodes to vary the weather a little. 
 
I understand that cute girls doing cute things is a part of anime these days, and in that, I suppose that the show delivers, as for the most part, they all play their cute reactions to the situations well, and things comfortably meander along, same as they ever were in each episode.  However, outside of the opening and closing credits, the Light Music Club seems to do precious little actual music composition and practice, which left me thoroughly confused, somewhat frustrated, and wondering if I was totally missing the point as people seem to love this show and recommend it as a must watch.  The whole show left me a bit mind numbed watching it.     
 
The big question that I’ve had a hard time answering after watching the first season is if the whole music club is really necessary to tell this story.  I’m not sure it added much.  I haven't watched the second season, and don't feel compelled to so I can't say if it gets better in that regard. 
 
All said, I didn’t get too much out of K-On!, as perhaps I was looking for something a little more substantial (I realize that may be misguided with a show like this).  When a song is actually played by the group, it’s decent enough to watch.  The problem is that this happens so rarely that it’s just not enough to really make up for the problem of it being the same thing over and over each episode.   
 
There are shows with characters that are interesting enough to make you want to see them interact in various situations and the comedy or drama involved will make it entertain you.  This show did not make me like or care about the characters enough to have that same reaction, but I could potentially see how some types fans could really enjoy it.  There are people who really like the cute character archetypes and the one trick thing, and this could end up working for them.  We all have guilty pleasure shows that aren't amazing, but they're comfortable and make us feel good.  Perhaps this is that for some people.   
 
Outside of watching K-On! because it’s well known, I can’t really say that there’s much to recommend here to someone who isn’t a fan of the slice of life genre.  It’s probably inoffensive enough to watch with just about any audience I guess so it could probably be something to watch in a club or something.   
 
Bottom line is that I think there are more compelling things to spend your limited viewing time watching.  I’m not going to recommend anything specific, but I’ve seen better more recent slice of life shows that left a stronger impression on me.   
 
It's not totally devoid of entertainment value, but I can't recommend this over other stronger shows.  You aren't missing much here.

    This is an overall review of the entire anime line. Possible spoilers ahead. 
 
1) STORY (9/10) 
 
The K-On! franchise tells a story of five girls in a high school music club. From the get go, it is clear that the show does not wish to move beyond the silliness and heartwarming-ness of slice-of-life comedies.  
This does not make the story "worse" as compared to other dramatic storylines. The story focuses on portraying the school life of a group of wacky and cute girls. It is clear that the story establishes a beginning in S1E1 and a conclusion in S2E24. 
The reason the story is rated so highly is because although it is true that the plotline barely moves unless it has to, it does not fail to portray a sense of progression throughout the series. Be it the realisation that fun times must come to an end, or the enactment of countless comedic scenes, it is not until the very end of S2 that viewers finally realise that have formed some kind of connection with the characters.  
A story that drags viewers in if they wish to lose themselves in this whimsical world is a good story indeed. K-On! tells us what the story will be about from the very start, then proceeds to fulfil that promise from start to end. 
 
2) ART (7/10) 
 
There is nothing outstanding about the art. This does not mean, however, that it is poor art. Just as we cannot explain why we love certain genres of music, we cannot explain why the illustrations here are, simply, good. A good attempt would be to point out the crisp, consistent, almost stencil like presentations of both the characters and settings.  
Whether drawings are pleasing is ultimately subjective, but to me, the art in this anime is pleasing enough. 
 
3) SOUND (8/10) 
 
As a music-themed anime, it would be in poor taste to invest less effort into the anime's sounds. Again, music is a subset of art, and is as a result subjective. 
I find the light and carefree music choices appropriate given the theme of the show. The songs composed by the K-On Club are catchy and mildly exhilarating.  
 
4) CHARACTER (7/10) 
 
The show employs cliches in anime character design, but there is absolutely nothing wrong with that. To create enjoyable, relatable or impactful characters is at the forefront of character design, and even though some may disdain the many cutesy moments the anime has to offer, at the end of the day, intrigued viewers come out of each episode a little happier. Given the light-hearted direction the show has chosen to take, it has done appreciatively well. 
 
5) ENJOYMENT (8/10) 
 
The show is enjoyable if you wish to relax after a long day, or are not looking to invest a boatload of emotions and thought into watching a rather lengthy series (and a movie).  
The anime intends to be fun, and should be watched for fun, and nothing else. To watch this with the wrong mindset would be to do a disservice to both the show and yourself.  
You will find yourself enjoying this show if you chill out as much as the girls in the anime do. 
 
6) OVERALL (8/10) 
 
K-On! cannot hold a stick to dramatic plot-driven shows or emotionally charged stories that impact viewers on a personal level.  
But most importantly, it DOES NOT NEED TO. K-On! is an anime that wants to have fun, and it does a wonderful job at it. The creators abuse their limits of not having any limits, and bring to life a crew of characters that are sure to cheer you up. If you're up for it.

    I'm disappointed with this anime because it would've received a higher score if only it hadn't introduced the new Light Music Club member. Her existence raised a concern I didn't even know existed: Why isn't there much actual band shenanigans? Then I remembered: Oh yeah this is a Cute Girls Do Cute Things anime where they're obligated to center 70% of it on cute tea drinking and cute cake eating while making cute noises and cute faces. All the aforementioned I actually do love in anime, but when you bring in a character whose sole purpose is to point out the flaw of the club and unintentionally make all the other members appear as one-dimensional douchebags, it's awkward.  
 
"Can we practice?", "When are we going to practice guys?", etc. You've got three girls wanting to play around and have fun, while you've got the other two wanting to do the actual club activities. I felt terrible throughout the second half of the anime because all I see is this poor new girl being dragged along on all these different jamborees and forced to overindulge in food and fun. Then the other girls play it off as a comedic gag when really it's unpleasant. I want them to have unadulterated fun without coming off as completely insensitive and lazy douchebags. When you introduce a girl who conflicts with their personalities and quirks in such an awkward fashion, it gets thorny, making the viewing difficult. 
 
Overall, I'm glad I saw this anime because it does its job well: being cute and not much else. 
 
Oh, also the few times they do play their instruments and sing it's fairly decent.

    Every genre has its entries that define how you should do a show of this genre. K-On! is the king of CGDCT/Slice of Life-Moe anime and shows what to expect of the genre, it gives a good idea of if the genre is for you. 
 
Personally, I don’t need a great story of any story at all in a CGDCT anime or even basic things like character development. A good CGDCT-show can focus on its two main aspects: The cute girls and the cute things they are doing. Add some music of magic or any other fun thing, it should be fun, and you are on the best way to make an entertaining and light-hearted piece of animation. 
 
In K-On!, we follow four girls and their teacher living their carefree lives with drinking tea, eating cake and sometimes actually practicing for their band. There isn’t any bigger plot or conflict, they just handle different everyday situations with their different characters. Just like every Slice of Life show you’ve ever seen.  
 
Characters are the main aspect of any Slice of Life show, and K-On! Does a pretty good job here. Every girl has personality and are characterized enough to make them different from each other. We have the lazy, but caring girl, the adult, but shy girl, the over-energetic girl and the rich and calm girl. In my opinion, the teacher really stands out here, she tries to leave her wild youth behind and become the loved and respected teacher she wants to be, but she also wants to be friends with the girls and make daring costumes for them. The cast works well together and you end up loving them, not for a specific character, but for their interactions and friendship. Everything you could imagine them doing can be justified by one of the characters. They are having a training camp in a huge house at the beach? Mugi’s rich parents own it. Need some amazing costumes over night? Sawako can make them. Forgot to get permission for sleeping in school? Good thing we are friends with the president of the student council. 
 
Music is always matter of taste, but I really liked it because it's light-heated and really suits the girls' personalities. 
 
In conclusion, K-On! suffers from the same problems many CGDCT and SOL anime suffer from. If you the characters, the whole experience is ruined, because the whole show is focusing the characters. But if you start to like the characters and their quirks, you start enjoying every minute of the show, seeing their friendships develop and overcoming every problem they encounter. This season is in my opinion the weaker one of the two, in season 2 they do more interesting things and there is some conflict and character development.
