    K-On! Is a show that bases its appeal almost entirely in the relatability and evolution of its characters and its ability to create a light, fluffy atmosphere that viewers, given the time, can easily fall into. This review will cover the essential elements of the series using the component-by-component format and will be pertaining to only the first season, as I have not seen the second. Enjoy… 
 
Story - 6: K-On’s story is enjoyable and light, which is all it really needs to be. The four girls come across an abandoned club in their high school, The Light Music Club, and the first two to stumble upon it, Mio and Ritsu, act as recruiting agents. Once they find two more girls to make it qualify as a club, the story gets going (by its standards). The following events are fairly mild and, objectively, uninteresting. If you find yourself getting frustrated watching this show after a few episodes for this reason, just keep in mind that a gripping plot couldn’t be farther from the appeal of K-On!; rather, what the show goes for is a story that exists as nothing but a blueprint of sorts for the characters to interact with and make their own. This is where the life comes from in K-On!. Of course, characters will be covered in detail later in the review, but I bring it up now because the show’s story is just about pointless without them. You might be thinking “then why aren’t you giving the story a low-ass score if it is so weak on its own”, and you’d be right about it being weak on its own, but what’s important to keep in mind is that, while the characters are tailored to the story and make it unique and interesting, the story is likewise tailored toward the girls and takes adequate steps to make sure they are all put in scenarios that work well with their characters, which is not something that is necessarily simple at all, especially looking at it from an entertainment perspective. All things considered, K-On!’s story is adequate and lays a solid foundation for the more intriguing aspects of the show. 
 
Art - 9: The animation and overall artistic flow of K-On! comes across as fairly simple and run-of-the-mill at first, particularly in its color scheme, I found. However, within a few more episodes, it becomes increasingly apparent that most of the way the show is animated is calculated and for a purpose. I noticed this almost bouncy feel in the manner of the girls’ design, particularly in Yui’s (which couldn’t be more fitting for her), and this helped in giving the girls’ antics, as well as the show as a whole, a more loving and airy tone unlike any other show I had seen. This is truly what hooked me about K-On! to begin with. Beyond this common factor, though, each girl in the band is animated a tad bit different, each having her animation tailored to her. Mio’s elegant, sturdy design is reflective of her level-headed, and almost mother-like nature toward the girls, Ritsu’s sketchy and almost sharp design is perfect for her off-the-wall shite, and Tsumugi is animated in a bubbly, lovey-dovey sort of style, representative of her role in the show as literally the girl who is made to be likeable beyond the point of being realistic. Aside from this, there is a general feel of completeness and attention to detail in all the settings the girls are in, contrasting greatly from the manga, which failed miserably in this department (as well as art in general). Another important thing to bring up about the settings and backgrounds is that they work to make up for the almost bland color schemes of the girl’s designs in some scenes. With that said, the art of K-On! is one of those previously mentioned aspects that brings the simplistic story to life, and is satisfactory in just about every regard. 
 
Sound - 8: The soundtrack of K-On! is frankly unmemorable, which is a shame because every other aspect of this category is absolutely stellar. The OP and ending are perfect and reflect one of the balances that is one of the show’s goals to flesh out; the dichotomy of the girls’ seemingly simplistic and joyous time together (the opening) and their individual insecurities (the ending). Of course, considering this is the sound category, I would need to mention that the music of each the OP and outro are perfectly fitting respectively, as well. In addition, the voice actors match this quality with beaming energy and engagement being brought to each of their roles, thus creating a feeling of consistency in what this show is producing sound-wise, as well as making the characters feel more lively and fun beyond their writing and artistic design. Overall, the sound in K-On! is good enough to match the other aspects of the show, which, considering how highly I regard K-On!, is saying quite a lot. 
 
Characters - 10: This is the selling point of the series, as K-On!’s characters retain a balance and chemistry that is yet to be matched by any slice-of-life, comedy-centric anime (or show, for that matter) that I’ve seen. Truthfully, the whole appeal of their bond as a band (almost rhymed) is that they build each other up and possess what each other lack, which varies from member to member. While this is faaaaaaaaaaaaar from the most original premise in existence, K-On!, if anything, is a testament to the argument that what a show (or any visual storytelling medium, for that matter) comes down to is not themes or premise, but the execution thereof. The way I see it, classic stories of all mediums, while built around solid themes, are not considered genius for their theme or message, but how the writer conveys it to the audience in a relatable and interesting manner; execution. Any oaf can say “my story is about friendship and the importance of bonds”, but not just anyone can make a cast of loveable characters using expert writing and art to make people give a shit about said message. I would summarize each character to further exemplify what I’m saying, but I’d rather just give an overview as to justify giving them a perfect 10, which is what I have done (and besides, I already covered in brief their personalities, excluding Azusa in the Art section).  
 
Enjoyment - 9: With a show that is so solid in virtually every category, I don’t think it comes as a surprise that my enjoyment of this series is high to say the least. The writing behind K-On! clearly takes into perspective the entertaining of its audience, as almost every scene involves the previously noted chemistry between characters, and the all-too-enjoyable art style. That said, the show did feel a bit slow in the beginning and I found myself constantly on edge over the fear that this was going to devolve into just another directionless, lackluster slice-of-life shitfest. However, as I continued, I found myself becoming strangely attached to the characters and the amazing amount of consistent badassery each had to offer. Later, as their insecurities became fleshed out, I felt sympathy for them, as well, which was the last piece in the puzzle of my complete admiration for the series. This caused me to acknowledge and respect how well this show knows its audience (including people who generally aren’t big slice-of-life fans). Virtually all tastes are considered and the show never pandered me too much with one thing. All in all, my enjoyment of K-On! is just about as solid as the show itself. 
 
Overall - 9: K-On! is a show that does exactly what it set out to do and more. As I have only seen a few of the light-hearted anime of its nature, I don’t speak from a place of expertise, but I can recognize a good show when I see one. This series is fun, charming, and relatable and left me with a sense of completeness after viewing it. An important thing to note about the seemingly trite theme of friendship is that it is not an inherently harmful thing to incorporate into a show, and that it gets its bad rep simply for being used in media that generally is pretty repetitive and pointless. Thus, an action-oriented fan such as myself can easily find a solid foothold to enjoy this show on. Giving this show a fair chance would be in any anime fan’s best interest, and I hope I presented my thoughts on the matter in a manner that is clear, interesting, and informative. 
Thanks for reading :3!!

    Story - 7 
 
The story can be viewed in one of two ways: 
1- Yui's quest to join the Light Music Club and the club's attempts at playing shows, improving etc which is present in few episodes. 
2- A general following of the light music club's endeavours and their cutesy antics, this story being the more present one. 
 
If you're looking for a strong story driven and episodic anime then this most likely won't be for you, whereas if you want an anime that doesn't require a lot of thinking and allows you to zone out or just put on when you want to have a laugh K-On! should be right down your ally 
 
 
Art - 7 
 
The show's art isn't exactly great meaning it can be hard for it to stand out in a crowd but it is still nice to look at. The characters in the anime all tend to be easily distinguished from each other although during certain scenes such as when they are asleep the characters can be difficult to tell apart (especially Yui, Ritsu and Ui) 
 
Similarly the character's designs (cute girls, big eyes etc) are pretty similar to those of other characters in other moe; also taking from its ability to stand out in a crowd 
 
 
Characters - 7 
 
Although the characters are most likely based on the archetypes of most moe characters you shouldn't let that put you off 
 
All of the characters are easily likeable in K-On! with each of the main cast having their own role in drawing viewers in 
 
Yui (guitarist and vocalist) plays the role the ditsy girl that provides the set ups for a majority of the funny moments and bounces off of Ritsu's character very well 
- 
Ritsu (drummer) is best compared to a tomboy as she enjoys playing the drums and scaring the other characters (mostly Mio) 
- 
Mio (bassist and vocalist) is the serious character that usually tries to keep the band on track. She's also quite the scaredy cat which sets her up for multiple scenes of other characters scaring her 
- 
Asuza (rhythm guitarist) is also a more serious character that tried to keep the band inline. Asuza is the youngest in the band and often falls victim to being treated like a baby by Yui 
- 
Mugi (keyboardist) is the rich girl that allows the club to indulge in opportunities such as visiting summer houses during the holidays in order to practice and also provides the expensive treats that often distract the club from working. She is often seen taking pleasure in the simple things in life. 
-- 
Sawa Chan (teacher and advisor) acts as the club's advisor, she is more often than not shown as being a sweet charger l character that is loved by the students for her kindness and beauty however sometimes her character takes a full turn and acts more hostile due to her guitarist past 
 
 
Sound - 8 (Dub sound) 
 
Considering this anime is about a light music club and band the music is few and far between although the music IS pretty good when it does finally come into play and generally has an upbeat tone that gets your body bouncing even if you don't notice straight away 
 
The acting is also done well with the characters sounding pretty much as you'd expect: 
Yui being high pitched and cutesy to match her ditsy personality. 
- 
Ritsu having an almost raspy voice to match her tomboy tendencies. 
- 
Mio and Asuza both having serious voices for the most part to compliment their work-then-play attitudes. 
- 
Mugi having a high 'wow everything is amazing' voice to match her habit of being happy 90% of the time and finding everything (including silverware cleaners) to be cool and interesting 
- 
Finely Sawa chan for the most part having a sweet voice letting her maintain her image of kind teacher, while also being able to switch to a volatile, raspy tone when letting her inner rock star shine 
 
 
Enjoyment 7 
 
Overall the show is pretty enjoyable if you enjoy anime that don't follow a strong plot and generally don't have a very episodic nature. While watching K-On! you can relax, turn off your brain and just mindlessly tune in, all while being provided with laughs. 
 
You can also opt to be an active viewer, fully engulf yourself in the show and take in the show's small pieces of plot and receive a little bit more enjoyment from the anime 
 
 
Overall - 7.2 
 
In conclusion K-On! is quite enjoyable and is a good way to provide yourself with some laughs, it has likeable characters, catchy music and a nice art style so it'd be recommended that you watch it rather than take a pass on it.

    K-on was something that I initially thought was something that I would not enjoy. So I unfortunately skipped it for the past... say, 2 years. So I finally managed to watch the first episode and I had to say the story and the animations and art style were very much to my liking. I personally want anime to look nice and flow smoothly, which K-On did have. The characters, instruments, settings, and various items were very well drawn and matched the theme of the anime. But I felt that this was the icing and decorations on top of a very satisfying and moist sponge cake. Not only does it look good, but it tastes good too. The story is absolutely adorable, funny, and gets you everytime.  
 
The characters each have their own unique personality, and adds to the story plot. Did I mention that they were all very cute girls? That's another plus in my book. I could probably go on about why I love this anime and why I regret not watching it sooner, but that'll take another 5  paragraphs so I won't do that. As for dislikes... There wasn't much I disliked actually, tid-bits here and there that I noticed, but just aren't large enough for concern. But these are my personal thoughts, I love anime so I might be a little biased. But please give K-On a try if you haven't already seen it. You won't regret it.

    ( Guitar Riff ) K-on! 
 
As a quick description of the show is perfection un-perfected. Shows exactly how important progression is to a pretty stagnant genre. In the moments where the show shines it shines bright but in its slow areas it noticeable. 
 
Story: 4 
 
If such a thing as a "slow start" exists, it is present in the 1st season of K-on. Apart from the fact that the last main character isn't introduced until the sixth episode, there is very little progression until Azusa shows up. 
 
Art: 5 
 
A little disappointing to say the least. Inconsistencies in facial expressions and overall medium quality of the show make for a forgettable setting and atmosphere. 
 
Sound: 9 
 
Cagayake Girls, My love is a Stapler, Fuwa Fuwa Time, and Don't Say Lazy; They are some of the best anime songs ever. Cagayake Girls is an okay introduction that is a bit too energetic for the show. Don't Say Lazy on the hand is a better closer as it slower and feels a bit powerful witch is suited for Mio who is the character who sings it. The OST fits like a glove in almost every scene as it captures the mood of the scene. (on a separate note: if you can the best song that is from the fictional band is calles "Happy!? Sorry!" but does not show up on the show)  
 
Character: 9 
 
The lifeblood of any slice of life story is its characters and K-on! does not disappointment. Although a little cliche with adding an energetic character(Ritsu) and a tsundere(Mio), K-on does well to make the interactions between them as realistic as they are entertaining. Each character is easily likable for certain perks that the show doesn't completely overexpose. 
 
Enjoyment: 7 
 
It will be very worth if you can get passed the first six episodes, which can feel like a chore and could've been done in three episodes. However afterwards the show is A-maze-ing. 
 
Overall the show is divided almost in half. The first half is inert and has little moments of merit. The second half is constantly moving and shines like diamonds. If you aren't patient enough to watch the first 6 episodes than you'd only need to watch episodes 1, 2, and 6 and fill in the blanks in between and you'll be good to go.

    K-ON! was definitely something that I could consider to be a very well done anime. This is obvious in so many ways, and it's safe to say that it should not be underestimated. 
 
The premise of K-ON! involves a group of high school girls who form a band through their light music club.  It might sound a little boring to some, but that all depends if you can handle a slice of life anime like K-ON!  Rest assured however, that this is not the only focal point of the series. 
 
For one, I personally loved the art.  It was unique in the way it's animated, and the characters are all drawn to be amazingly lovable.  In addtion, I would also say that this series might have some of the most likeable anime characters around.  While some might say they represent anime stereotypes, I will beg to differ in saying that they are actually unique enough to break the stereotype boundary.  
 
If you like moe, then this is definitely an anime for you.  I don't think I've seen such a cute anime as this one, and it especially gets more so with the inclusion of Azusa in the last five episodes.  There are not enough words to describe just how moe this anime gets.  K-ON! also made me laugh a lot, and it definitely has a lot of parts which will make you smile or grin without a doubt. 
 
Music, as the title suggests, is obviously one of the main things about this anime that make it so enjoyable.  I've always found myself attuned to jazzy and more danceable music, but I can't say that I did not enjoy the ending and opening sequences of K-ON!  The songs are quite catchy and they have a kind of 80s vibe to them, so if you're a fan of that, you'll definitely like K-ON!'s music. 
 
Storywise, K-ON! was relatively decent in that it focused mainly on the lives of the characters and the upcoming preformances that the light music club had to get through.  I never found any of this boring, luckily, so the anime doesn't falter storywise.  Character development doesn't happen much beyond the band getting more coherent towards the end, but the characters keep all their charm throughout the thirteen episode run. 
 
All in all, K-ON! is a very good anime, and definitely worth watching if you're looking for a good laugh, lots of moe goodness, and musical content as well.  I give it a 8/10 only because it didn't really blow my mind or keep me really attached like other animes have, but it was still very entertaining and enjoyable.

    K-On! Never in my wildest dreams did I think I'd enjoy an anime like this. Boy, oh boy. 
 
Story 10/10 
If you started watching K-on expecting an actual plot, then it is you who is lacking, not the anime. That's like going to a Michael Bay film and expecting to get a nuanced classical drama. It is a 10/10 story, precisely because there is no story or plot (or rather a minimal one at that). You can pick it up at any episode and follow along. Sometimes, you just want to kick off your shoes, cozy up under a blanket and watch a cute little anime, you know? And I cannot overstate the importance of not having any romantic aspect in this show. Seriously, if they had done that, it would've been a 2/10 show for me. Moving on... 
 
Character 10/10 & Art 10/10 
Imagine the cutest and clumsiest little dog you can think of. Now turn that dog into a human. You have Hirasawa Yui. 
 
How the hell can something be this cute! Props to KyoAni. With Clannad, Hyouka and Inu Yasha, they were already up high in my list. But now, with K-on, yeah... Yui's character and interaction designer, or maybe it was the manga artist who did this in the first place, you sir, are simply amazing. If it were up to me, r/aww would have nothing but K-on gifs and screenshots. 
 
Watching the Hirasawa sisters interact is simply, healing. Hearing Yui say "Ui" is panacea. 
They rank pretty high up in my top conversational duo list, after Araragi/Senjougahara, and Holo/Lawrence, and Hachiman/Haruno and Araragi/Shinobu, and Araragi/Tsuki, and... well, the Monogatari series is cheating. But you get the idea. 
 
Not just that, Yui just friggin lights up any and every scene that she is in. An MC that actually grabs and shines in every possible moment? It's Yui. No one can compare here. She 'makes' the show. And keep in mind, I'm not taking anything away from the other characters here. They're all so friggin adorable. It's just that Yui ties everything together. 
 
Sound 8/10 
All you voice actors, you simply could not have done a better job. But for a music oriented anime, it could've had some better OST. 
 
And finally, this anime might not be for everyone. People tend to expect different things from different shows for different reasons at different times. I was just frustrated by a couple of anime that I watched recently (Noragami, looking at you) and wanted to simply watch something where nothing happens. I'm really really glad I picked up K-On. Anyway, if you think, 'fun things are fun', you know what to do. 
 
Say, "Moe Moe Kyuuun" and give in to happiness.

    [STORY: 3/10] 
"K-ON!" is not a very story-rich or enticing show. It wants to be a slice of life, but one that does little to tell a good story, which is something pretty important for this type of show to do, or it just gets boring fast. Cute girls doing everyday things isn't enough to keep me interested. 
 
[ART: 7/10] 
The art is above average and the character design is very well done, but that's all I can say. Nothing is spectacular about it that makes it stand out besides the carefully crafted cute characters. 
 
[SOUND: 6/10] 
Characters can be annoying and loud, but the voice actors do a good job at least. Music for openings is pretty enjoyable, but otherwise it's pretty mediocre. 
 
[CHARACTER: 6/10] 
There are some enjoyable characters and some lackluster and generic ones, but the character design is done very well, as I said earlier. Nothing much to say besides that. 
 
[ENJOYMENT/OVERALL: 5/10] 
"K-ON!" could've benefited from a more interesting series of events that strayed away from the generic "lets do club stuff and be high school kids" idea that a huge chunk of these slice of life shows try to replicate (and only a few get it right). It definitely has standout character design, but lacks in most other areas and really brings it down to an average rating.

    I've seen the K-On! name around for years now, and had never really been interested, but figured it was on my 'eventually gonna watch these list' and it was it's turn in the line up. So, I started this anime expecting very little, and as far as story art and characters, this anime delivered exactly what I had expected. What wasn't expected was how enjoyable the delivery was. 
 
As a slice of life anime, stories tend to take a back seat to the characters and their interactions, what K-On! did was took extremely generic character types, relatively cheap looking artwork and somehow made something that melded these qualities together well. 
The background tracks never stood out, but that is maybe a good thing since you instead focus on the things that are happening and how the characters interact. To that same end, the BGM never hit a nerve for me in feeling out of pace or out of place with the show, so I would say their use of music to fit the scenes was done rather well. The music for the performances and bits where the girls are actually playing anything did seem to be well done and to the credit of the animation team, they did seem to take some note of hand positioning on the instruments while the girls are playing the instruments. 
 
While K-On! doesn't have any qualities that are revolutionary or groundbreaking, it delivers on just being very fun to watch. In a way, the show itself is a lot like the characters. No special parts individually, but when combined it somehow works well enough.

    The Positive Side: K-on! Is often cited as the definitive “cute girls doing cute things” show, and on that end, it certainly delivers. 
The show follows four high school girls who form an amateur rock band and learn to play.  The four main characters all have distinct personalities and quirks, and it can be a lot of fun watching them goof around.  Yui is an over-grown child, fun-loving, naïve and easily distracted, but in the rare moments she manages to focus, her energy and passion is inspiring.  Mio is the brains of the group, keeping the less dedicated girls on task, but her authoritarian attitude is at odds with her self-doubt and constant fits of panic.  Ritsu is the cavalier and irreverent tom-boy, perpetually teasing Mio.  Mugi, the rich girl, is the most soft-spoken member of the group, but she has an inquisitive nature and a desire for personal accomplishment that separates her from the cliché of the rich, spoiled brat.  While the characters are exaggerated, they each have a certain emotional depth, and play off each other quite well. 
While there is quite a bit of slapstick, some of the comedy is surprisingly subversive and original.  The series opens with our heroine running late for the first day of school.  I flat-out rolled my eyes as she dashed down the street, obligatory toast in mouth, facing numerous delays before bursting into school… and immediately realizing that she misread the clock, and wasn’t late at all.  Realizing how badly my own cynicism and knowledge of clichés had misled me, I had no choice but to laugh, both at the cleverness of the gag, and at myself. 
The central goal of the rock band the girls form gives the show more direction than some Slice of Life series have, though this also can make it a bit frustrating that more time isn’t spent on the advancement of the band.  Appropriate to a series about a band, the music is very well done.  The opening theme has a peculiar blend of heavy metal and J-POP, with a driving, energetic beat that is sure to get stuck in your head. 
 
The Negative Side: While the comedy is usually pretty solid, the show makes a running gag of Mio having constant emotional break-downs, and this is honestly more uncomfortable to watch than it is funny.  There are also a few rather Haruhi Suzumiya-esque molestation jokes, but these are kept comparatively mild and infrequent.  While the music is catchy, the lyrics are pretty vapid, and the soundtrack is rather limited.  None of these, however, are the biggest problem I have with the series. 
The biggest problem I have with this series?  No lesbian make-out sessions. 
…I’m being serious.  Wait, don’t close the review yet, I’m going somewhere with this, I promise! 
There’s something supremely unsatisfying about a show where everyone is obviously gay, and yet no-one is allowed to have an explicit gay relationship.  There’s little excuse for this kind of timidity when Sailor Moon gave us an out-and-out lesbian relationship all the way back in the freakin’ 90’s.   
If the series’ homoerotic overtones were played purely for comedy and fanservice, I think I’d be able to forgive the lack of relationships, but K-on! tries to have it both ways, playing lesbian attractions for drama without actually admitting that said lesbian attractions exist.  Episode 11 centers around Mio spending time with Nadoka (a girl in her class) and Ritsu becoming jealous as a result.  Ritsu tries to hide her feelings, playing around and teasing Mio as usual, but her jibes are noticeably more mean-spirited and unnatural.  The other girls notice that something is wrong, and make anxious, desperate efforts to lighten the mood and continue their practice session.  Ultimately, these efforts fail, and Ritsu leaves in frustration and disgust, claiming she can’t play today.  After getting to know the characters, this is a genuinely painful scene to watch.  It’s obvious that Ritsu has feelings for Mio, and equally obvious that she needs to come out and express those feelings.  And at the end of the episode, she just, sort of… doesn’t.  Her feelings of jealousy magically go away, and the show continues like nothing ever happened.  Mio spends some time with Ritsu caring for her while she’s sick, which is sweet, but neither of them makes any kind of meaningful approach towards the other. 
So… why not?  Why, after the obvious emotional turmoil and build-up does the series fail to deliver any kind of meaningful emotional climax?  Are the writers simply afraid of screwing up the show’s dynamic by introducing a romantic subplot?  It seems a bit odd that they would display that level of attachment to the status quo when they introduced a new major character half-way through the series.  It almost feels like the show is fetishizing homosexuality, portraying homosexuality as something too taboo and naughty to be portrayed openly.  
While K-on! succeeds as a slice-of-life comedy, it squanders its own potential by refusing to admit the relationships it teases.  While I enjoyed the characters and came to care about their struggles, I couldn’t help but feel that they emotionally fenced-in by their own writers.  While it’s not a bad show, I don’t recommend anyone rush it to the top of their “To-Watch” list, either.  If you want a light-hearted comedy about cute, gay schoolgirls, go watch Sakura Trick instead.  The music isn’t as great, but it also doesn’t keep its lesbians suffocating in the closet for thirteen episodes.

    4 Girls in High School start a band...what's not to love??? 
 
So K-On! is our journey into Sakura High, where the "Light Music Club" is in need of a guitarist. Yui, who wasn't expecting any of this from the club, suddenly finds herself in a band and cranking out tunes on her lovely Gibson Les Paul.  
 
The story arc is there, unlike some SoL comedies, so that was a big plus for this one. It does a great job of balancing out the main story with happenings and little side stories that add to character development. It's also a fairly good pace since everything being about band struggles would make the story go stale kind of quick (been there, done that). Some of the tropes used in all animes are there, but the show is masterful at how/why they find themselves in these locales. A rehearsal space that's at a beach house is much better than just "Lets go to the beach because...reasons!!" as an excuse to see the girls in bikinis. It has the common elements, but with enough of a twist to make them more believable.  
 
Art was pretty good, but seeing more of the girls playing along with the music would have been nice. It was cool when it did happen, but on a few scenes you felt kinda slided when they would skip the performance. It's not a super big gripe, but I felt it detracted enough from the show to mention it. The instruments all look great and the music videos are so cheesy that they are just freakin awesome....but I'll save that for another section.  
 
Sound...the acting and of all things the FREAKIN MUSIC is AWESOME in this anime! Yeah, the OP is a little poppy, but a lot of the songs have a kick to them and are well-composed. I would argue that the ending theme "Don't Say Lazy" is perhaps one of the coolest songs from an anime I've ever heard (even better than "Between You and Me" from Kuragehime, my previous favorite). To get off that for a moment, the voice acting seemed pretty good in the sub (which I opted to watch instead of the dub). The girls personality and cadence shines through despite the language barrier for me, so it makes the sub pretty enjoyable to watch. I'd highly recommend skipping the dub on this one, not sure how they handled the songs they performed, but that may be interesting to watch (I'm guessing they just did them in Japanese). The song titles are hysterical as well (My Love is a Stapler!!), but I can't talk enough about how much I like "Don't Say Lazy", just do yourself a favor and jam out to it when you get a chance.  
 
Characters were neat and enjoyable, though the mix on some of their personalities seemed to be strange choices (Mio is a scaredy cat?). I really thought the dynamic was fine from the get-go with all the girls, but later on Azusa seemed to be a pretty useless addition IMO. She's kind of mousy and quiet like Mio, but without as much focus on success or artistic brooding. They tried to take Mio and mix her with some Yui moe elements, but it feels like she gets in the way all the time. Why mess with something that already works? It's like making Pinky and the Brain and Larry...all you are adding is more characters for a couple of moe jokes that just felt useless. Every time I look for merchandise, I always want it with just the original 4 girls. Azusa aside, all the other side characters seemed to fit and felt natural. I'm a bassist so I think Mio is cool, but I really do like all the girls (except Azusa).  
 
This show totally deserves a perfect score on enjoyment from me. The music is great, the stories and jokes are enjoyable too. The band elements and musical jokes/references make it all the more entertaining for me since I play bass and guitar as well. I'm sure the story arc has been done before, but it felt more unique than many of the SoL comedies I've seen before so it was a welcome change of pace. You get excited to watch the show and it makes me want to pick up my bass or guitar afterwards and jam!! Definitely puts me in a good mood.  
 
 
 
All in all it's a great show, definitely worth watching if you are into SoL comedies and a MUST see if you are a musician in any capacity. Get ready for the songs to be stuck in your head for days on end, but the thing is you enjoy having them in there! I'd say the only negatives are the performances they skip in the show and the addition to Azusa which I felt was the big blow to this anime. Without Azusa being in there, I would have given this show a 10 overall, which I don't give out lightly. She'd make a better side character or perhaps a fill-in or sub for Yui in an episode or two, but making her a main character just felt like dead weight. It's a shame, I really wanted to give this show a 10. Don't let that keep you from watching it though, I loved it so much that I bought a t-shirt!!

    After reading different reviews about this anime, I prepared myself for the worst. Like no story, no interesting characters, no logic or morale, only fan-service moe and kawaii. It, of course, true in some ways, but completely untrue in others.  
 
I do not see much anime of this type (or any other) and do not truly understand what moe means, so I write about my fillings on this anime with regular words. 
 
First of all, this anime can cheer you up and calm you down after hard work, or even motivate you for doing what you want. And yes I am talking about K-On. Still, it is mostly kawaii and moe (whatever it means), so not everybody will notice anything else, except cuteness of anime. 
 
==Story== 
All anime is about four (five) schoolgirls who love to drink tea with cake after school studies. And it is all. Oh, no, they also play in school music band, but mostly it is tea. There is no story and the whole season, and mostly there is no story at one episode either. It just events which can happen in school. No hard conflicts to resolve, no unsolved mystery to find out, no high goal to reach. Is it bad? Not for this anime. Girls just flow with events around them and give us their happiness and love. The story is not needed here, so let's go on. 
 
==Characters== 
They are great! It is generic characters, but that is not bad either. Absolutely naive and cheerful Yui, serious and fragile Mio, vigorous Ritsu and so kindness Mugi. Part of all of them live inside everybody (and this is good parts), and in this anime, they just divided into different persons. It is fun to looking on their mutual study and entertainment.  
 
==Music and art== 
I love OP and ED really much. (ED - is best motivation song of the last time). Also, there is decent music on their scene appearance. For me it's enough, but it is hard to notice that anime is about music club.  
 
Art - is good, I like this simple drawing. Simple but effective.  
 
==Enjoyment== 
Why did I enjoy this show so much? Because it fit to the real world. It's an ideal world where is no problem, and lady luck is at your side, it is the world where you dream can become true, people around are kind and ready for help. It looks so different to the real one, but it not unconnected at all. This anime make you believe, that real world is not so bad, and it really is. You can have some dream to follow, as heroes of anime do, and you always can had some tea and sweets with friends. There is no need to bury you child ambition and beliefs, sometimes it help to become happy. And this anime dig out this childish out of you.  
 
 
I do not recommend this anime to everybody, and my score is little overrated, but this is my filling for this anime.

    [Contains mild spoilers] 
 
At first glance, K-On could easily come across as just another cute anime about cute girls doing cute things. But what makes K-On rise where lesser anime fall, is in the way it tells its story. 
 
A commonly used trope in modern comedy is to create a static world and fill it with dynamic characters. This means that the humor then has to come from individual situations, since the world as a whole never changes or develops. A perfect example of this is The Simpsons, where the crazy adventures always are forgotten by the next episode. The world resets. 
 
This is where K-On differs in the best way possible. It doesn't let story suffer because of situational comedy; instead it lets the comedy serve the story. Every skit always seem to have a purpose in driving the plot forward. A good example of this is when the girls band together (pun intended) to earn enough money to buy a guitar. Sure, a lot of situational sillyness occurs during that scene; but because the story calls for the girls to get money, it doesn't feel like a sketch or a throwaway gag.  
 
However, with that being said, K-On's story really is a silly and light hearted one; which means that if it focused too much on the plot it would come across as taking itself too seriously. So it's all about finding that sweetspot between comedy and plot; and boy did K-On find it! 
 
I would also say that the character development in K-On is extremely realistic. A common criticism aimed at shows such as this one is that "nothing happens". And granted, every episode just seems to be about the girls sitting around drinking tea all day. "Where's the story?! Where's the plot progression?!", I hear you say with your voice filled with critique and elitism.  
 
But here's the thing, the fact that nothing seems to progress IS what makes it so realistic. Real life progression sneaks up on you. If you were to compare yourself with you from two months ago, I bet you wouldn't find a whole lot of differences. Same goes for you from two months ago and you from four months ago, and so on. And yet, I'm convinced that if you were to compare yourself with you from a year ago, he or she would seem like a completely different person.  
 
The same goes for K-On. Just because you didn't notice the changes, doesn't mean they didn't happen. If you compare the first and final episode of the series, you'll notice that a lot of things has changed. Four charachters that started out as complete strangers would now die for each other, and a charachter that had never played guitar in her entire life now rocks it out on stage in front of a huge audience. Where's the story? where's the plot progression? Well, it's right in front of you, just open your eyes. 
 
K-On isn't The Simpsons. The world never resets and the humor is never pointless. The world is dynamic and the characters have memory. And most important of all, it ends on a completely different note than it started on; without ever failing to entertain. This is why K-On is a great experience.

    The Story: 5/10 
 
 	It’s freshman year and Yui coming to the realization that she hasn’t done a goddamn thing with her life, realizes it's time to shame up and join an after school activity. She becomes interested in the light music club thinking she could play the castanets, but boy was she wrong, but she still feels obligated to stay in the club, so after a bit of awkward peer pressure she decides to continue to be part of the Light Music Club and learn guitar so she can continue to eat the delicious dessert Tsumugi brings in every meeting. The pacing of the plot is pretty minimal and the actual story is pretty bare bones, with slice-of-life high school problems filling out the moments that aren’t holidays or concert performances. I doubt anyone is really looking for a gripping plot when watching K-On! anyways they’ll probably instead have a squuuuuuueeeeeegasm at how moe each member is,and over  just how darn quirky they are. With K-On! it isn’t about the destination, but just how many adorable moments one can squeeze out of 13 short episodes.  
 
Characters: 6/10 
 
	First of all you got the MC, Yui Hirasawa she’s really naive and airheaded, but she can do great things if she puts her mind to it, oh she also loves sweets along with everyone else in the Light Music Club. Mio Akiyama is the bass player who is intelligent, shy, a bit of scaredy cat, and probably the most talented musician of the bunch, Tsumugi Kotobuki is the keyboardist, who’s thoughtful, nice, rich, and also a bit of an airhead (I feel like she is the least well-developed character of the group, although none of the main cast is all that well rounded). Ritsu Tainaka is the drummer and the club president, she’s a bit rough and is childhood friends with Mio, thought she acts really similar to Yui at times. Azusa Nakano is the final band member, and is the rhythm guitarist I assume. She’s a year younger than the rest of the members, and she is definitely the most serious of the bunch. I love her coming in, and being put off by all the tea drinking and cosplaying the LMC does during most practices, and I despised how they showered her with attention by forcing her to try on outfits and making cat noises it was pretty uncomfortable.  
 
Art: 7/10 
 
 	The show looks well enough for being in the moe slice-of-life genre and a lot of shows that KyoAni does tends to look pretty gorgeous (like the first image result when you type in Sound! Euphonium Reina I mean, wow). Everything about the art design is either sufficient or god damn adorable. The animation on the other hand is average overall, even the band’s performances don’t look all that fluid or smooth.  
 
Music: 8/10 
 
	K-On! doesn’t disappoint in the quality of the songs in the show, but I just wish that there was way more actually songs in the series, since I don’t remember very many. Both the opening and ending for season 1 are praiseworthy. The show is also pretty hard rock sounding during intro then blasts into a girly frilly rock song, that reflects that actual tone of subject matter of the show to a tee. It’s timid and precious at times, and then crescendos into a chorus of youthful exuberance  and rainbows and The Ending is exhilarating and really gives off the vibe that they are an actual rock band, and not some tea drinking amateur high school band. Also the costume design and transitions showing each band member and their instruments are really sleek and eye-popping. I love both the opening and ending for season one, and are my favorite parts of the series for sure. 
 
Enjoyment: 7/10 
 
Despite the rarely seen plot, K-On! can actually be addicting in short bursts, It’s like the sweets the girls devour every afternoon, it’s best short and sweet, and if you too many in a single time it will leave you with a heartache. It’s sort of the the anime equivalent of Animal Crossing, I mean it’s nice to check in every once in awhile to see how your town and neighbors are doing, but there is only so much you can do in a single visit, and can get boring and drawn out pretty quickly. The best this for sure is the music, and if anything just check out the openings and the ending for season one, and if your interest in the characters then watch the show, but if it those don’t do anything for you then don’t bother with K-On!.

    There are a lot of things I could say about K-On!, but to sum it up in one word, it's great. 
 
One of the main selling points for me, and I'm sure a lot of others, is the art. The art and animation are absolutely outstanding, and it's one of the main reasons I began watching the show in the first place. The crisp, clear lines and fluid animation really bring the characters to life, especially during their musical performances.  
 
Now let's talk about the characters themselves. There main cast is composed of four main characters, at least in the beginning. There's Mio Akiyama, the bassist of the group, Tsumugi Kotobuki, the keyboardist and my personal favourite, Yui Hirasawa, the lead guitarist and lead vocalist, and finally Ritsu Tainaka, the drummer. Each character has a very clear and distinct personality, and displays this quite well throughout the show, despite reusing a lot of the same type of jokes to do so.  
 
What about the story? The story is....less than stellar, compared to the rest of the show. A lot of the episodes end up having a lot of similar scenarios, like the group spending most of their time in the club room, drinking tea. Of course, this isn't to say the story is bad by any means. A good portion of the episodes try and keep a fresh topic, and generally accomplish that.  
 
Now, the music. The music in the show is really excellent. The songs they play are catchy, as well as the soundtrack throughout the show. The concert scenes are definitely among my favourite of the whole season, and these scenes are where the animation really comes to life, with the characters perfectly synching with the music they are playing. The music the band plays is really high quality, and it's worth replaying the scene just to hear the song again. 
 
Overall, the anime is very good, with a ton of excellent qualities. If there were any complaints to be made, it would be that the jokes get a little dry, and the story line wasn't the greatest. I hope people find this review helpful, and thanks for reading!

    K-ON! is one of those rare shows that features music as the over-arching theme. It can be a hit-or-miss, considering who it is targeting to and what your own preference of music is. 
 
Story: 7 
The series follows Hirasawa Yui and how she gets herself involved in the Light Music Club. Even though she has little to no musical talent, she joins the club as their lead guitarist. The show was set to be simple -- nothing too fancy and nothing too bizzare. The comedic part of the series is extremely light and nothing that will make you burst into tears, but that's my own preference. 
 
Art & Animation: 7 
Kyoto Animation found that making shows more "moe" like would bring in the viewer's attention -- so they did it. Again, like the plot of the story, nothing too fancy. Each character was drawn to look cute with not that many details. The art for the ending was a lot more detailed, and that would've gotten me a bit more attached to the series if it was like that. Moe art for me, ehhh. It's not something I would prefer, but it works. 
 
Sound: 7 
Again, music is all about preference. It is a hit-or-miss for you if you like pop music. There is a big risk in making a series solely on music, since you don't have much to fall back on. The songs were meant to be nonsensical and also added a small part of the comical element to the series. Try reading some of the titles of the songs featured in the series -- it can be a bit odd. The lyrics are no different. Nevertheless, just about every song they have made is catchy and enjoyable. 
 
Character: 6 
I don't know what it is about having 1 of every character: 
Hirasawa Yui, the airhead and the main protagonist of the series. She gets the most development throughout the series, but it seems to lack at some aspects. (guitarist, singer) 
Akiyama Mio, a timid girl where memes of her spreaded like wildfire (Just search up Moe Moe Kyun and you will know what i'm talking about). (Bassist, singer) 
Kotobuki Tsumugi, the rich one out of them all that offers tea and cake just about every episode.(pianist) 
Tainaka Ritsu, the tom-boyish character of the series. (drummist) 
Nakano Azusa, the semi-serious character in the series only to revert into the fanservice cat cosplayer that everyone loves. (guitarist) 
 
What do they all have in common? Their enjoyment of tea and cake while being extremely lax most of the time throughout the entire series... and being extremely moe. They all have a single specific characteristic that only they can have, leaving a lot to desire in character development. It develops a bit more in the second season, but this is just a review for the first. 
 
Enjoyment: 6 
It wasn't really a show that got me excited, or pumped to watch the next episode. It was more of a, "meh, i'll continue to see how it ends". It became repetitive and my enjoyment level slowly depleted as a result. When Azusa was introduced in the series, it gave me hope that it may get a bit more serious, but I was let down as she got more and more affiliated with the Houkago Tea Time band.  
 
Overall: 7 
I am not saying this series was bad. The plot of the series was to get a bunch of girls together to play some music -- and they achieved that. After that, there wasn't much following it. If it's not music, you just follow their daily lives at school, which just about every anime has adopted for some reason. 
If you want to expand your pool of music and want to just sit back and relax to a series that isn't taking itself too seriously, watch it. Otherwise, it's not something that you have to be extremely eager to see.

    K-on is a joy to watch.  
 
This is candy in anime form, sweet, lighthearted and inconsequential.  
 
The sound and art design in the series is fantastic, with excellent camera work.  
 
But I think where this excels is in the relationships between the characters. Everything they do together is believable and you really feel like you're getting an insight onto the friendship between these girls.  
 
Some might say there's not a good enough storyline, but I don't think an overarching plot is important in this case. This is a slice-of-life, its supposed to focus on characters and how they interact, not deal with major morals and life choices.  
 
K-on! is a cute and beautiful show about high school girls being high school girls. I think it's Kyoto Animations best work and some of the finest in the genre.  
 
If you enjoy slice of life, you will enjoy k-on.

    This is not going to be some amazingly professional review, criticizing every last detail about why I like or dislike K-On!. Instead, this is going to be my personal opinions informally thrown out there to tell people what this show is about. If you're looking for a step-by-step breakdown, don't read this review. Also, this review will not contain any spoilers. 
 
K-On! revolves around the local school's Light Music Club, which is basically just a club where everyone in it is in a band and they create songs, play instruments, all that stuffs. When the first year of high school starts, 2 girls find out that the club is going to be disbanded due to lack of members (nobody is in the club), so they decide to take up the club and own it. Gradually more and more girls join and there ends up being 4 of them fairly early in the series. Later, a 5th, Azu-nyan, joins about half way through. Now, the main story of K-On! is... well... I guess it's about them trying to make music and become a well-known band or something...? But honestly it's about them eating cake and drinking tea. After school each day, they have their "practices" or "rehearsals," but they don't actually do a lot of practicing or rehearsing. Instead, they mainly sit around and talk while eating cake and drinking tea, which is usually very comical. The main aspect of this anime isn't necessarily about music, but more about being cute and funny. Yes there are music aspects as that's basically the whole plot and story of the show, but it's not as dominant as you'd think. For me, I'm glad. I liked just sitting back watching cute girls do cute and funny things, all while stuffing their faces with cake and tea. That is basically the summary of this whole anime: Cute girls do cute things while being funny, also while stuffing their faces with cake and tea. That's it. That's the show. Now, when they actually play songs and etc. and preform concerts, the music is awesome. The sound quality throughout the whole anime is very crisp and nice, and the songs are cutesy and very enjoyable. The characters are very enjoyable as well, as I said earlier they're all cute and do cute and funny things. I really liked Mio who was the shy and scaredy-cat one of the group. They all have their own unique personalities and each one of them plays a different instrument. Well, I guess that's the review. 
 
Yes, I understand that this was a gigantic run on paragraph listing random facts about this series, but that's just what it came out to be. Again it's very informal and I'm just spewing out information about why I like this show, so there you go. You should definitely watch K-On!, because it's relaxing, cute, and thoroughly enjoyable. Unless you're looking for a deep plot or conflicts, because it has practically none of that. 
 
10/10 - Would eat cake and drink tea again

    As you may have heard, K-On is a pretty cute show. If you hadn't heard...it is. As many others have said, don't watch it if you don't like cutesy kinds of shows.  
 
K-On is the first full season of anime I've ever completed. I'd seen pictures from it around and I finally decided to watch it to see what it was about. I was pleasantly surprised.  
 
K-On a feel-good kind of show. It'll make you smile. There's nothing too serious going on. There's nothing perverted. It's good clean fun. It would be hard to get offended watching this show, no matter who you are. It's silly high school girls being silly. That's an aspect I really love about the show. It lets girls be girls. It's not trying to turn them into something they're not. They're young girls having fun together, facing joys and struggles in a school club. The lack of drama might be unrealistic, but is nonetheless refreshing.  
 
The characters are all adorable and unique. I personally could identify with different aspects of each character, but I'm sure many people identify specifically with one or the other since the girls are all very different. Mugi, Mio, and Azusa are all shy, but in their own way. Mugi is content being quiet. Mio is more serious and paralyzed by embarrassment. Azusa is reserved and always wants to do what is proper. And then you have your extroverts, Yui and Ritsu. Yui is in her own little world, amused by cute things and food. She's lazy, but charming. Ritsu is more hyper and crazy, always wanting to have fun. These characters together form delightful and inspiring simple friendships. 
 
I didn't watch the series all at once, but spread out over a few months. At times it seemed to jump around a bit. But there is no complex plot. You could really jump in at almost any time and things would probably make sense for the most part. Some episodes just felt like they didn't really matter though, such as training camp episodes or the extra winter-day. They just diverted from the plot, although it isn't complex in any way. Also characters such as Azusa and Sawako Yamanaka seemed random and unnecessary to add in, but once they were there I appreciated them. 
 
I was expecting more original music from the girls, but sadly it wasn't delivered. Much like Mio and Azusa are at times disappointed with the group's progress, so was I. There were only a few songs they wrote. And they were only briefly featured.  
 
K-On holds a lot more potential than it actually presents in many aspects, but it is enjoyable nonetheless because of its innocence.

    Let's dive into an anime from a few years ago! K-on! I know many people have seen it but i felt like writing this even though it's from quite a long time ago, well... simply because i wanted to acknowledge this anime in its entirety. If you do happen to read this, i just wanted to let you know my feelings for this show is genuine and not at all biased. Basically my aim for writing this review after the show has aired for so long is simply because like me, there are some people who are only catching up to some old animes a few years after they air and i wanted to let them know how i felt about it. 
 
Just a heads up before we start, but i REALLY LOVE THIS SHOW. It's one of the (if not the only) casual comedic high school slice of life storyline that i've re-watched time and time again. It was also the first actual anime (that i knew of) that i watched before getting into anime. Even when i compared it to some of the other casual anime (especially the newer ones), it stands out as one of my top anime of all time. It's not even an exaggeration to say that if not for this show, i probably would not have bothered delving into the anime world. As usual, i'll try to keep my joy restraints in check and give an honest and unbiased opinion. 
 
Story: 8/10 
 
Like i said, the show is nothing short of spectacular for me and the story itself is one of the reasons why. There are many reason as to why i gave the story an 8. It's interesting, funny and enjoyable. However, there is one thing that tops everything listed before and that is the portrayal of friendship. The friendship between all the characters in the story is astounding and heartwarming. Given that the roster of characters are small to begin with, the growth of their relationship as friends over the span of 2 seasons are something to be admired and warrant an involuntary smile to anybody who watches it. The best part of it is the friendship is not instantaneous, but instead nurtured ever since the beginning of the first episode until the very last episode which makes the ending episode even more heartbreaking. Of course, the story flow is important as well and boy does it not disappoint. During my viewing of the show, never once had i thought that the show was rushed nor were there any plot lines that were lacking. It was as if you were watching a show where the characters start from the literal beginning and slowly mature along with you, the viewer. Everything in the show is paced orderly and not skipped ahead, or left out to the viewers. Every musical skill and talent, character and personality growth, and overcoming obstacles are tackled in a proceeding fashion alongside the viewer. Not to mention, the comedic value in the show is great in itself, and every flashback story is entertaining and in some cases, touching. This is perhaps everything in a nutshell.  
 
Art: 8/10 
 
For an anime of that time, the artwork is quite amazing. However, as with all casual anime, albeit amazing, it doesn't really stand out much. So why such a high score given (8) ? Well, here's the thing. The artwork is highly compatible with the music as both complement each other perfectly. With already amazing graphics for a casual anime of 5 to 7 years ago (not sure), the way it works together with the music is really a masterpiece. I would say that both these 2 work together so well, it always creates a very fitting atmosphere for the show. Rainy scenes with relaxing music, or the mischievous tune with playful cutscene.  
 
Sound 10/10 
 
10.... is the highest score i could give. I highly regret not being able to give a higher score for the music and soundtrack deserved way more than a measly score of 10. Let me summarize: Music, epic. Soundtrack, holy goddess of amazing. First impression? Never had a better one. The fine line that always separates perfection and great is the first impression and K-on did an impressive job of that. Every literal song in the show hits me so hard the first time i hear it. From the vocal music to the instrumental music, every one of them felt different and gives off a different kind of joy and pleasure to my ears. From a fast playful tune, to the rainy solemn peaceful music, from the light and jumpy music to the rock and fast paced jam, all of them were enjoyable. And the way it complements the artwork gives it even more of a bonus! Sure, most other shows have great music too, BUT the only difference is that K-on had a much higher impact on first impressions than the others do. A very fine example of this would be Love Live. Love Live is one of the most popular series ever made, and one of the most popular idol band to date. I love all the Love Live songs too but it took some getting used to before favoritism unlike K-on which became an instant like. 
 
Character 10/10 
 
If you watched the show, then you wouldn't even need to read this to know why it got a 10. All of the characters are extremely likeable and adorable. One thing i wanted to talk about though and that is the connection of friendship bond between the characters. The bonds of friendship between the five main characters are no joke as the developers made them and created the story such that every character has an interwoven interaction and bond between one another. It's not just 2 pairs of best friends or flimsy and simple friendships. Throughout the whole 2 seasons, there have been episodes that illustrated how every character feels about one another, even the characters who seem to have no relation to the other. There are even some episode that are dedicated to deepening the bonds between two seldom interacted characters, resulting in interweaving the bonds between all of them even tighter, making them more than just close friends, but portraying them as a family. Of course, the personality and development of each character is extremely well balanced, so that no one outshines the other. All in all, this show has an extremely good character balancing along with story character growth and development. 
 
Enjoyment: 10/10 
 
Needless to say, after all the things above said and done, i really enjoy watching this show as it fills me with waves of emotions every time. With great plot, art, and epic music and character, i highly recommend you to watch it if you are a fan of music, comedy genre. Even if you are not and just want a good anime to start off your otaku life. I still recommend this. Give it a try, i promise you won't regret it ;)

    K-On! was the first anime I watched after visiting Tokyo and wow it changed my life!! 
 
Story: 
K-On isn't a traditional slice of life anime with a generic storyline about achieving ones goals by the end of the series. And this detour from convention is what brings about the comedy and truly touching moments in K-on. 
 
Art: 
The art follows that of a moe anime, especially during comedic scenes. However, the general animation is detailed and serene when it needs to be. This is specifically shown during the opening credits and the intricate details of the band's performances. 
 
Sound: 
For an anime focusing on a girl's high school band, the OP and OST of K-on is right up there with the best musical animes. Whether its Fuwa Fuwa Time, U&I or Tenshi ni Fureta, its performed and expresses perfectly the feelings of the characters. I love the fact that when Yui loses her voice in before one performance, you can here the croakiness when she sings backup vocals. Talk about attention to detail!! Furthermore, the voice actresses even learnt their respective characters instruments and performed a live concert which is totally awesome and shows how much work and dedication was put into this anime. 
 
Character: 
The characters are well fleshed out and given a good balance of performance and screen time. Each character brings a different personality to the group and this brings about the conflicts and comedic moments in the series.  
 
Overall: 
I never though I'd get into slice of life or moe anime, but K-on changed that and to this day is still one of the best animes I have ever seen. I highly recommend this for anyone looking for a good laugh or enjoy pop/punk rock music. Shame they didn't continue the series onto when the girls start university as depicted in the manga.

    Wow.  
 
I'm just taken back by such an experience, K-on is truly a masterpiece. It has a cast that rivals Evangelion and Monogatari. Art and animation that's striking a memorable. I've never laughed harder at anything. K-on is the most fun I've ever had with an anime. 
 
K-on is simple, yes but complex. Each member of the cast was perfectly built to mold into each other's personality while standing out on their own. I could just watch them all talk about wet bread and still be entertained.  
 
Each girl has time to really grow as a person in small ways over the course of the series. Each one learns a little more about themselves in silence. Just with stares and quick glances we're put into the world of this character. This isn't mentioning Yamada's amazing direction. 
 
I have many scenes that are forever in my head. For emotional moments and the funny ones. So many little gags and leg movements are playing in my head right now, and that's great. It's a testament to how well Yamada can direct. She can make a scene stick with you. I will forever laugh at Yui playing the castanets and when Mio fell over. 
 
That scene in particular is funny because we expect a panty shoot but get a rice bowl colored to Mio's paintes which is goofy and funny. And it's shoot in a way in which you'll remember it and giggle a little when it comes up in your mind. But it also still appeals to that crowd giving them the idea of Mio's panites. It's a win win situation.  
 
The more you watch the show the more you laugh. You become friends with these girls and laugh with them. You can guess how they'd react to situations in real life because they feel like real people to you. 
 
The feeling from K-on is one no other anime has ever recreated. Well many may try to be as great they all can't see how everything adds up to make K-on. 
 
K-on's great because of the stellar art and animation, and the lovable real characters.

             Basically this show is like a cleaner version of beck with all girls and more comedy. It centers around our ditsy main female character Yui. She is trying to decide what club to join in her school. All of the others that she's looked at weren't really her thing. They either required to much work, or were complex things that she couldn't understand.  
 
	As you can tell Yui is a really lazy girl. The only thing she works hard at is eating really, and of course guitar later on. Being this kind of girl, I was surprised to see her voiced by Stephanie Sheh (I watched the dubbed). Mainly because a lot of the roles she has been in (that I've seen) have been quiet, and shy girls. Like Hinata from Naruto, or Orohime from Bleach. So seeing her voice a more outgoing character was a new experience. However, she pulled it off better than I thought she would so I was happy. 
 
	Yui then decides to join the “Light Music club” thinking that their name meant that they played light music. Because apparently she play this...clicking type instrument, which it's name I'm spacing on, back when she was younger. However after joining she finds that not to be the case. 
 
	Desperate for members, as well as a guitar player, the club is still one short after Tsumugi joins, they are ecstatic when Yui shows up. However Yui had planned to quit right away, so when the other three members all were showering her with gratitude and sweets. It made it really hard for Yui to quit. However, after confessing that that was her purpose in coming here. She does end up joining after the three tell her that they will help her learn guitar. 
 
	The whole show is basically about how the four grow as a band members and friends, along with gaining recognition at there school. There are hardships along the way, but they all manage to work there way through it. The comedy in this is also something that will have you rolling on the floor laughing at some points. 
 
	Plus, if you have seen my anime list. I've seen almost every romantic comedy ever made. So watching this show, as it doesn't have romance, was a tough choice. However I did, and I was not disappointed. This show is definitely in my top 10 now. 
 
	Cons of the show: These are the problems I have with K-On! First of all, my biggest problem was how quickly Yui learned the guitar. In one of the episodes she played a solo out of nowhere, completely throwing me off. I have played guitar for almost three years now, but I still could never play that solo that she played. Not to mention how Ui was able to play it when Yui was sick, like she had been playing for a long time. All I'm saying is the guitar is harder to learn than this show makes it out to be. I know. If you want a show that show's it more accurately than watch Beck. 
 
	My only other con is one that bothers me every episode, and that is Tsumugi's eyebrows....yea okay not really a con, but they still freak me out. 
 
	Story (9) Not to original, but It is played out really well none the less. About a band working together to make it big, along with everyone's problem's. I know I've mentioned Beck a lot in this, but that's because It's the only other show I've watched like this. It does follow Beck's storyline pretty close, except for the fact that Beck is looking for recognition in the world. K-On is looking for recognition in just there school pretty much, along with gaining more club members. If you like lighthearted comedy's that like to have fun with music, and not take it too seriously. Than K-On! Is better for you than Beck. 
 
	Characters (10) The characters in this is what make the show what it is. Each character is unique in their own way. Mio with her shyness, and her fear of just about everything. Ritsu with her crazy antics, and childish manner. Yui with her....ok Yui is a lot like Ritsu actually. Except for Yui is really lazy. Tsumugi with her awkward love for girl's interacting with another, and fascination with simple things. And Azusa (band member that comes later after seeing the club play live) with her desire to work the club harder at their music, along with her cute antics that are forced upon her by the other members, mainly Yui. 
 
	Though some characters can be pretty cliche, but honestly who cares. If you like it than why does it matter if it's already been done. After all, you can't just eat one potato chip out of the bag can you?...Did that make sense?...I think it did. 
 
	Sound (10) I've never really know how to judge sound by. Is it for the music that plays in the background? The emotion that is felt throughout the show? Or the voice actors, and sounds of objects in the show? Whatever it is I don't know, but I'm going to make sound the music in this, as It's a show about music. 
 
	Every song in this show is really catchy. Though, many of them have some pretty bizarre lyrics. But, since the songs aren't in English themselves, I'm ok with that. My favorite song is definitely the ending song for the first season. I would watch it every episode, It never got old for me. 
 
	Animation/Art (8): The way I see it is there are four kind's of animation. There is simple and cute, simple and ugly, complex and beautiful, and complex and overdone. This show is of course the simple and cute one. It's not amazing animation, but it's a really cute one. Nothing unique about it, but I still really like it. Another similar animation that comes to mind when I think about it is “Love, Chunibyo & Other Delusions.” Though Chunibyou is more closer to the complex and beautiful, they are very similar in style. 
 
	Enjoyment (10): I freaking enjoy this anime more than eating Pocky while playing Soul Calibur. It's definitely something that I would recommend to anyone who likes the lighthearted show's with lots of comedy. Even if your not a music fan, I'm sure that you will still enjoy this show. I'm a music guy though, so that's why I love it so much. 
 
	Overall (10) Technically it get's a 9.4/10 which rounds down to a 9, but I just think it deserves a 10. Judge me if you will, but that's what I say.

    K-On is about a group of wacky group of girls who form a band and the comedy of what all four girls get into.  
This is another high school comedy styled anime, their adventures are funny and the show itself will make you smile due to the close to stupidity moments most of the girls have. It's a good anime, its funny, its colourful, it's well animated and even the English dub is decent.  
 
 And its about music, its about girls playing different instruments and singing songs, so people who enjoy music would find appeal in this anime.

But overall, the anime is what it is, a silly, slice of life high school comedy, and for it's genre, it's good.  7-10 overall

    Overall: 7.5 
 
Hirasawa Yui entered high school, without knowing what to do. Later on she joined Keion (light music) club, and began her carefree life with her classmates, practicing guitar and eating puddings.  
At this age, there are perhaps hundreds of animes about "cute girls doing cute things". Among them, K-ON! already seems old and rather mediocre. Still, it's done pretty decently.  
The whole series feels laid-back, bother-free of reality. I should say I rather dislike this mood. (I would say Love Live is better in this term) But it does have two more realistic girls, and I like them. And, if you are seeking this particular mood in the first place, you probably won't find it disappointing. Indeed, those realistic elements add flavor to the interaction of 5 girls as well as whole enjoyment for audience.  
I've heard that KyoAni was in lack of money when they made this, so no wonder its art quality, although good, is not as good as other KyoAni series. Yet its simplistic drawing style gives a particular feeling, blended with its general mood. (sort of like Lucky Star) 
The songs are pretty enjoyable to listen, especially the op and ed, really cool.  
If you like slice of life shows with a little reference to reality (by reality, I actually mean the harshness of life), you should definitely check this popular series.

    K-On! is a show that will not surprise you or make you cry but it is most certainly worth the watch if you are just looking for something casual! 
The series has no distinct story elements that make it stand out, the entire show is essentially a generic Slice of Life / Musical anime with a fantastic premise and soundtrack. 
 
We start off with our main character, who is quite the airhead, joining the "Light Music club" with no musical ability at all, the members of said club convince her to stay despite the lack of music skill and she decides to purchase a guitar and learns it in a few episodes like some kind of god. From there, the anime introduces the teacher and a few other characters who add to the story overall but nothing special. The characters in this series all have there own traits that make them easy to seperate from one another and are very happy most of the time, but once again, nothing special. 
 
The animation is crisp and playful at the same time. There is so much emphasis on bringing these characters, the music and there surroundings to life which I have to give Kyoto Animation credit where credit is due. They have shown time and time again with series such as "Hyouka" and "Clannad" that they can emerge you into an animated world with the great amount of effort that goes into producing each series. 
 
The tracks "Cagayake! GIRLS" (OP) and "Don't say 'lazy" (ED), they are very catchy and give you a sense of what you want out of the music that the Light Music Club will play. Sadly, they only play like 2 songs throughout the entire series and they don't live up to the two tracks previously introduced.   
 
In conclusion, I believe this show to be worth watching despite some of the disappointments it brings. K-On! is a very cute, lighthearted and adventurous series with colorful animation and a good OST. Even though the story and aspects of the characters don't deliver, everything else does. 
 
Enjoy your tea and cake everyone!

    Honestly, I am very surprised at how much I liked this show. I felt great unease while watching the first episode and the only reason I continued watching was because I'd already downloaded all the rest as well. At first it just felt like I'm not meant to watch this thing - now that I'm done with it, I feel a bit like Azusa after she joined the light music club, thinking "This isn't for me, what's with all the cuddling and being cute and childish"...my opinion has changed as well as hers. 
 
The animation quality didn't seem that great when I first got into the show (compared to Haruhi for example), but later on I started thinking it was perfect. I don't know if that's also a matter of adjusting or if the animation quality really increased exponentially as the show progressed. As for the music and voicing, it's extraordinary. Every character has a lovely distinct voice and every single song has gotten into my daily playlist. There isn't much to the plot but I guess the creators of this anime were going for that "light" feel here as well; let's just say it certainly is original for the most part and enough to keep you glued to the screen till the very end. 
 
K-ON! may seem simple at first but trust me, it's an acquired taste. The more you watch it the more you like it. I'm not the type of guy to watch something like this and I was still smiling in an odd, benevolent way throughout the show, watching it was pure joy.

    K-On! is probably one of my all time favorite animes. It's so fun and so very cute! 
 
I enjoyed the dubbed version, despite the criticism it receives- I think the voices matched the characters very well. This anime is outstanding mostly because of the relationships the girls were able to develop.  Not only that but you can't help but love them.  
 
Ritsu and Mio are already friends in the beginning but you can see their bond grow as well as with the other girls. Yui is the cutest character ever, she gets distracted and she just finds ways to keep them all together even though she messes up more often than not.  
 
The only flaws in this anime was that their parents were always gone- for the entire anime. I mean, that happens in a lot of animes but, c'mon, do their parents really like travelling more than seeing their daughters grow up? (mainly referring to Ui and Yui). 
 
At the very end I cried my eyes out- it was just so perfect. I really recommend this anime if you're into Hetalia or perhaps Lucky Star, because even though there is a plot, it moves very slow and some episodes are random- but you get used to it!!
